In a way though, the art not doing much contributes to the charm. The setting still looks fairly pretty and some of the magic effects used by the main characters are polished well enough. CG has decent value. Not great, but fair enough and it doesn't drag the show down too much.


Sound (7/10)


Like the art, the sound doesn't really show for much new, but it accommodate the style well. The opening and ending are largely alright, but the background music (or occasionally lack thereof) contributes well to both the comedic dilemmas and what's going through a character's mind. Megumin for instance gets seemingly epic opera chants whenever she gets confident in her explosions, and it doesn't always pan out in an epic way. Like the art, it's nothing new, but it suits the style.


Characters (8/10)


What really makes this show subvert expectations and stand out are the characters. Some would assume that the MC being with several girls would be every guy's dream. Not in this case, where the primary joke is how impractical they really are and how it turns the MC's life into a post-living nightmare stuck in this other world. 


Speaking of the MC, Kazuma himself is someone you'd expect to be bland, basic, overly nice, overconfident and good hearted. But he's not. Kazuma is quite frankly a total smartass, and doesn't really value his teammates when it comes down to it. Where the show takes his rather condescending attitude is again, part of the comedy. On the other hand though, his actions never go so far as to be totally unrealistic and in that sense, he provides a great amount of understanding with the audience because, quite frankly, getting constantly frustrated, feeling the need to be towering above others, wanting to do something for selfish pleasure, and outsmarting anyone who crosses you would be very common for the group he's meant to represent. It never gives him too much without kicking him where it hurts, and never drags on suffering for it to feel like too much. The balance makes the character work.


As for the other characters, you have his three teammates he ends up with. Totally dysfunctional party crashers. 


First you have Aqua, the goddess Kazuma stole from her high throne to take along with him. She has adorable moments, but is also incredibly attention seeking, overdramatic, and has high power, but at the expense of common sense. That she's often condescending subverts her cute appearance, and like with Kazuma, the show will do a lot at her expense over its run. 


Then there's Megumin, the Arch Mage and my personal favorite of the group. She has extremely powerful explosion magic...but can only use it once a day, then becomes incapacitated. So Awesome, but Impractical. She has a lot of dramatic flair, and her voice actress does a great job of pulling off her dramatic moments. There's a lot less to her expense, but how the show uses its meta/subversion comedy style still falls into effect.


Finally, there's Darkness, an incredibly durable Knight with high stats...but she can't actually hit a target for anything. She's also treats pain in a...more enjoyable way than most. However, this isn't her whole character as the contrast between honorable knight and masochist makes her character feel like a character rather than a one note Butt Monkey. All three of them ultimately make it far worse for Kazuma than better, but they do grow closer by going through all this together. 


Everyone else basically fits their part in the comedy, from the "I just want to be noticed" headless horseman, the incredibly by the book legendary hero, a thief girl, and a couple of the monsters met along the way, which have bigger roles than you'd think in their episodes.


Overall, I'd say Konosuba is a solid watch that maintains consistent quality. The comedy may not be for everyone, and many elements of the show fit themselves to that comedy style, but the way the show is presented in contrast to your expectations made this show worth a watch. It's only 10 episodes, so it won't take up that much time, and Konosuba is something that'll likely stick in your head with how everything was handled.

omg. this is the best comedy anime i have ever watched! I'm so glad there's going to be a season 2. Well, there are a lot of pros for this anime but there are a few cons, such as it being too short, therefore the plot felt rushed and it ended up negating the fact that there is now no plot and just comedy which kinda ticked me off a bit.
the transition from eps 8 to 9 and 10 was a bit like..... too much transition, we needed more, it just like SUDDENLY HAPPENED. Well, for those who like comedy, this is definitely the goto anime.


The art is pretty amazing, nothing really much to complain here. 


The OP i guess was okay and the ED was pretty bad. espeicially with how sesaon 1 ended, then all the sudden ED theme plays, it just didnt feel right of a transition. the ED in my opinion does not go well with the anime itself.


So overall, i enjoyed this anime, so many laughs and stuff. i would not recommend to those who want an actual story plot, this is an anime for those who want to have a bit of a giggle.

I enjoyed this anime in the sense that it was very comical and am sure that it would be one of my favorite animes in the comedy genre. This is totally irrelevant to readers, but it astounded me right after watching Re:Zero kara Hajimeru Isekai Seikatsu that there was another anime that had somewhat of a similar feeling in the beginning -- this one more comical of course. Back to my point. Overall, I enjoyed watching this anime as it gave a good deals amount of laughter and would recommend it to anyone who is looking for a good laugh. The development of the storyitself should not be taken seriously as the main core of the anime seems to be how they rally up their jokes and execute them. 


STORY: 7/10

A bit contradictory with a rating this fairly high to what I said above (the anime being less story oriented and more focused on executing jokes), but its story development still did aid in the jokes and overall comedic feel of the anime. 


ART: 8/10

Self-explanatory. From the thumbnails it would be obvious that the art would be good. Good, but not great, nor outstanding. Just good enough to pass the heightened expectations of anime viewers of the modern day. Just enough to pass as a standard.


CHARACTER: 9/10

I wouldn't have praised this anime for its comedy if not for how they developed and introduced its characters. I got most of my laughs from the Crusader because she really did twist a lot of situations around in a comedic manner. Every significant character contributed to the story, so I thought that they did a good job there.

NO SPOILERS BELOW
Story 8/10:  
The story has a straightforward "in another world" concept.  However that's the only thing that's straightforward about it.  As stated in the synopsis the goal of the main characters here is to "defeat the Demon King" and they could not be more ill-suited for the job.  I once heard this show described as "the resulting Dungeons and Dragons campaign from a group of drunk assholes who are doing everything in their power to derail the Dungeon Master's intricate story."  I also once heard the show referred to "It's Always Sunny: The Anime."  Both of thesedescriptions are very apropos, in my opinion.


Art 9/10:  

The facial expressions in this show are absolutely perfect.  Every emotion is expertly shown on the faces of the characters and you really get a feel for things like a character's disbelief or disgust even when no words are exchanged.  


Sound 8/10:  

I think what makes the audio really stick out in this anime is that you can really tell that the voice actors/ actresses really enjoyed working on this show.  There isn't really anything else to it.  There is no music that really sticks out but the dialogue is really is delivered very well so I think that can be forgiven.


Character 10/10:  

The characters are all incredibly well rounded and interesting and, perhaps most importantly, they all have great natural chemistry and every interaction with these characters feels genuine and is absolutely entertaining to watch.


Enjoyment 9/10:  

Watching the four main characters play off of each other to create a natural feeling comedy was fun.  There were a few scenes I found really funny but the entire show had me sensibly chuckling the whole way though.


Overall 9/10:  

This show is a fun sitcom comedy, but also an anime.  And it was fun.  When I sat down to watch it I watched through every episode in one sitting and I regret nothing.

KonoSuba takes the standard premise of a regular japanese NEET being sent into a fantasy world to quest and adds a twist - he was given the option of taking any single thing or person with him by the goddess of the afterlife, but the goddess was so insensitive to his plight that he decided to spite her by bringing her along. It's a smart idea, and the predictable jokes that result, focusing on how the goddess is actually fairly incompetent and unhelpful, are pulled off well, but it doesn't live up to the comic potential of its premise.
Most of the comedy in KonoSuba comesfrom the characters, who are all incompetent and delusional in different ways, with the protagonist - Kazuma - usually serving as the straight man, trying to stay alive when their idiocy makes all his missions go tits-up. Aside from that, some of it comes from Kazuma himself, with his cunning rule-breaking approach to solving problems in this RPG world, as he lies and cheats with merry cynicism in order to get money, level up, and defeat the Devil King. The setting itself is completely generic, and almost no attempt is made to mine humour from it or make it more specific and interesting. \n\n
Episodes usually follow the pattern of Kazuma and his team accepting a quest after some initial bickering, assuming it's going to be fairly straightforward, before it goes sideways on them and they have to improvise in order to win. The epilogue usually involves them losing the money they earned in some way, either to pay off debts or pay for the damages they made while fighting, so they go back to square one. With that obvious lack of development (although some incremental progress is made - they do each get slightly stronger and more accomplished), the show needs to be smarter and more engaging than it is to really work, but it's consistently funny enough to never actually be bad.

As every super-hyped season anime, KonoSuba caused more good impression than complying them. However is still a very good anime, with a little disappointment of “Is that all?”. Even for a non-declared Slice of Life disguised in an RPG adventure anime I expected more plot. Maybe is my fault, to think that would follow the same idea of another RPG adventure anime of the same year. Without further ado let’s go to the review:
---Story---
Actually the only disappointment in this anime. I really hope for an actual and good adventure plot (maybe because another anime in this year failed in such issue), but we all receivea compilation of side events that reveals a funny Slice of Life show. I do not wait for an outcome for the Demon King saga, or even a city changing. Besides that it’s a good (really good) comedy anime, avoiding as many cliches you can imagine and making you laugh when you didn’t expect to, not mentioning that Chuunnibyo reference. WANA NA WA MEGUMIN .


---Animation—

Very beautiful. The light on the face when Kazuma dies, the starred sky, that DNA animation (that was impressing), the ending that’s fantastic, those EKKUSUPUROSHIONS. It’s a massage to the eyes, cool and clean. It’s not an Attack on Titans animation, but it’s still great.


---Characters--

Actually the main attraction of the show for me. Every relevant character with unique traits and personalities, that only reading the subtitles you can find out who said this or that. A good development of their relationships that makes everybody an important piece of the story, without aside characters nor sidekicks.


---Sound---

Cheerful opening and ending, bringing to you the spirit of a funny and joyful world. Another good sound spec is the singular soundtrack of every girl in the show. Darkness have her own song to their masochists delusions, which is funny and, somehow, sexy, as Megumin have and also Aqua have. The songs are well planned, and well executed too, like when Aqua and Kazuma were sucked to that “Subarashii Sekai”, their voices distorted as they has distanced themselves, this effect is logical, of course, but it was well made in an impressive way.


---Enjoyment---

It’s a comedy show to a comedy fan, so the enjoyment is guaranteed. In short it’s the perfect anime to spend a good time relaxing and laughing, not a masterpiece, but certainly an anime that should be re watched.

Konosuba is a nice anime to watch if you're not in the mood for anything deep, depressing, emotional, serious, etc.. If you just want to laugh, smile, and not think too deeply for a while, then this is an anime for you. Join a lovely party reminiscent of a D&D group or a party from any major RPG as the main characters go about struggling to survive on a day to day basis to escape hunger, fight not-so-terrible monsters, and face off against the most fearsome nemesis of all: debt! 
So is Konosuba worth watching?
Story: 7/10
For a comedic experience, the story was fine for whatit was. The story has a pretty standard setup from the start. Our first main character, Kazuma, is a NEET who suddenly dies in an accident, gets the option to reincarnate in an RPG/fantasy world, and accepts the task of slaying the generic-sounding Demon King to stop the evils of this fantasy world and eventually forms a party with a goddess, an archmage, and a crusader to do so. While this premise sounds bland, as the story progresses you start to see a ridiculous RPG world where you can't help but want to watch what happens next. One notable thing with the story is that a lot of actions and events are connected, coming back in the story later either as small jokes or a hilarious consequence of the party's actions, which I find makes this world come more alive and vibrant as things aren't just done and forgotten right after. Where the story does fall short is virtually no progression with the main quest, but their focus on the characters lives and daily interactions make up for some of the story's short comings and doesn't hurt the show at all. One thing that did detract from the story was a few time skips later in the series that yank from experience and had the viewer filling in some big story gaps.



Art+Sound: 8/10

For a story set in a fantasy world, you have colorful art where everything is bright and wonderful. It is not very detailed and if you are familiar with the stories about Studio DEEN you might come to a negative conclusion for the art+animation before viewing, but the comedy fits the art+animation well and the art actually helps emphasis it. There is some art+animation that is awful (such as awkward jiggling boobs), but for the important stuff (Megumin's EXPLOSION and people's reactions) it works perfectly so that you can ignore the bad stuff and focus on the comedy. SFX and sound isn't super either, but the voice acting for this was superb and really helped drive the comedy. The OP isn't great, but sets a happy viewing expectation. The ED was better and has a nice homely feel to it to send the viewer (for me at least) longing for more of this world.


Character(s): 9/10

This is where the show really shines! Every character is designed with certain skills and personality where separately they'd be unremarkable and questionable, but in a party dynamic they clash and this creates much of the comedy in Konosuba. We have...


Kazuma: above average intelligence, very lucky, and naturally takes the leadership role in the party, but has no natural skills and is the weakest of the party. He has the most common sense out of anyone here and is an asshole to anyone who annoys him or pisses him off, which is pretty much all of his party members.

Aqua: a literal goddess with powerful holy spells and maxed out stats, but her only lacking skill is below average intelligence and terrible luck. Her intelligence stat reflects on her actual intelligence and she's basically an air-head and her bad luck can drag the party down with her.

Megumin: the archmage of this party to help the party deliver massive spell damage, but she only knows one spell (explosion!) and using it will physically incapacitate her for the day. She is obsessed with maximizing her explosion spell's power, refusing to learn any other useful spells.

Darkness: a crusader and the party's tank with high damage absorption, but she is unable to hit anything. She's also a masochist and would throw herself into the heat of battle just to get hurt, ignoring any planning or preparation the party might have planned.


Now throw them together into a party and this is just a comedy goldmine where everything that can go wrong... will pretty much go immediately wrong from the start. Despite the party's flaws, in critical moments, Kazuma's quick thinking (and his high luck) will push the party forward, though in all other moments the viewers will laughs at the party's antics and failures as they struggle to improve and become better people. Despite the party wanting to improve, there is very little in character development. However, this show doesn't scream for any characters to grow so I can let that slide. In fact, the comedy does well to keep everyone more or less the same and just focus on their interactions with one another and it's those interactions where we do see some insights into everyone and a little character development come from it.


Enjoyment: 10/10

Konosuba and its comedy may not be for everyone (different strokes for different folks), but I throughly enjoyed it from start to finish. If you can ignore the lackluster art+animation and lack of story progression, this is definitely a recommended watch for comedy. There are also some time skips as I mentioned earlier, but considering that this had to be condensed into 10 episodes, I can let that slide. If you find yourself wanting more Konosuba, have no fear for season 2 was announced for Winter 2017. Rejoice!


Thanks for the read!

This is an anime in the popular genre of "help I have ended up in a video game fantasy RPG world and ooh look at these stats." We've come a long way since .hack, and we're at the stage in which we're at the subversion meta-stage of the genre. Welcome.
Seriously, there's too many of these. Too many anime made up of made up video fantasy game land. I'm sorry when I said I liked Log Horizon.
This is about a NEET loser who ends up in a fantasy land with the best luck and mediocre everything else, and a goddess/high priestess with the best stats andthe worst luck. Oh, and there's the chuunibyou dark mage and masochistic crusader. Together they form... well, pretty awful team, actually. But hilarity ensues, and that's what keeps the story going.


Art is great, with restrained use of fanservice.


Sound is nothing to speak of It does not offend, and that's exactly as it should be. Well done.


Characters are messed up, and the synergy of these characters are what keeps the party going. 


And yes, it's enjoyable. Not a serious series--as you would have realized. I would still recommend it. It even ends well without much of a cliffhanger.

STORY - 8
ART - 10
SOUND - 9
CHARACTER - 9
ENJOYMENT - 9
Well, if you really are wondering what an anime would look like if it takes on the MMORPG genre in a hilarious fashion where all kinds of logic gets thrown out of the window, then KonoSuba emerges. My room was filled with confusing laughters watching this anime.
What you get from this show isn't overly complicated. They were aiming for the goal to nitpick, tease, and make fun of other isekais out there in a friendly way. And no, in case you were thinking wrongly, it doesn't rudely look down upon other anime of the sameparallel setting, a fantasy world of quests or magic or guilds or all kinds of similar elements out there (and cute girls too). It instead does it through a pretty mean and different way, where the poor male main character undergoes all kinds of situations that was just totally out of whack to what he was expecting. Seeing him slowly getting drained out of all the stressful events he experienced was very amusing to watch. It also didn't helped that his allies of girls were pretty much a bundle of outgoing strangeness that made his situation even more of a continuous wave of sufferings after sufferings. Their funny personalities matched flawlessly with each other, having interactions that'll make you chortle close to a laughable and pathetic death just like the male MC. Anyways, the base factor that made this anime so entertaining was definitely because of the characters. The world isn't really built much, and you won't get to see a rich environment full of intriguing things as it's pretty much a lighthearted, goofy show. Every episode is split into short scenes that slowly progressed towards the main goal of defeating the Demon King, but the seriousness of the threats took on a comical approach so there were no sense of danger whatsoever.\n\n
Surprisingly, the take on the audiovisual were quite superb to say the least. It really assisted the simple, comedic story in making the anime more entertaining because of the great visuals. Oh but firstly, maybe the animation can be kind of cringy during the more fanservicey scenes with all the unrealistic physics of jiggles and blah blah blah. It's animated well though, it's just that it was a bit too over the top for my taste. That aside, the fluidity aided the bright and colorful art style during all kinds of scenes. Comedy? Exaggeration and humorous facial expressions so check! Magic powers? Nice use of colors and effects portraying a beautiful set of abilities so check! Studio Deen also went one more step in making the characters not blandly talking while standing still, you know, like moving the mouth boringly that rejects all sorts of entertainment. This anime made the interactions between characters more engaging in a dynamic manner, not going with the statue-like poses found in other anime but having the bodily movements more lively and brimming with silly energy. And with energy, comes with it loudness. Hilarity ensued as each characters shout at each other, spewing out illogical nonsense from the girls, or deafened common sense from the pitiable male MC. Every dialogues were enjoyable with the passion coming from the voice actors. I don't know this but I feel like they had a lot of fun during their session voicing the characters to bring out enjoyment. Soundtracks also fits the friendly tone, along with the opening and ending song that were filled with a delightful atmosphere for the fantasy theme.\n\n
KonoSuba was simply so outrageous in terms of an MMORPG-related entertainment that I can't help but feel that it managed to win my heart over. While the darker, more serious anime fills you with addicting adrenaline, this anime pumps in an equally addicting amount of euphoria-inducing dopamine into you with a fresh source of absurd characters, simple comedy setting, and a radiating audiovisual. Added up together and it becomes a refreshing relaxation to just let all your laughs and pressures out of your body.

Amazing,my words cannot describe how amazing this anime is;If you want to have a laugh,get emotional,just chill,enjoy amazing sounds,enjoy many different perspectives and characteristics and at the same time has an amazing story and Two beautiful theme songs;
The opening song is amazing with it's eccentricity and action-themed style while still managing to be goofy
The ending song touches your heart,it is emotional and depicts a nice quiet calm life which Kazuma seeks to look after;while also maintaining his relationships with the girls in the RPG world. 
My favourite prersonal character is Megumin,she is obsessed with explosion magic and wants nothing to do with any other typeof magic;she is first introduced in episode 2 and ever since has become my favourite character of the show. The way she describes Explosion magic is inspiring;her resolve and strength to continue what she loves no matter what anyone else does;including frown upon it.\n\n
I actually like Darkness and Aqua at great extents aswell,I ACTUALLY LIKE EVERYONE!!\n
Even the Skeleton knight guy :p, Kazuma is...ugh!@

I think I know my tastes in anime pretty well and so when a friend recommended this show to me, I said I’d check it out but was pretty certain that I’d drop the show by the first episode. And going through approximately half the first episode, I’d considered it. 
The main character, Kazuma, with his very basic and unappealing attire, seemed to me to be another uninspired neet archetype, and the goddess he meets, Aqua, was also, at first, seemed to be some video-game-fantasy type archetype to please the male otaku audience that this anime is targeted towards. However, through their interaction, I realizedthat although what I’d said about the archetypes was partially true, what was also true is that there is a very healthy dose of self-awareness and fun. Aqua laughs maniacally at Kazuma’s fate and Kazuma is dumbstruck at his own fate and the frivolousness of Aqua, not at all how he envisioned a goddess. And Kazuma, as petty as he is, decides to go to the fantasy world, and asks to take Aqua. Now, Aqua is terrified, and even starts comically crying and distorting her face, with excellent animation to make sure the watcher knows it's all fun, while also setting up a sort of give and take motif that Kazuma and Aqua will have, usually with Aqua acting sort of prissy, and Kazuma ignoring her, and Aqua crying to Kazuma. The relationship can get a bit repetitive but with the addition of other characters and their own fairly specific relationship with Kazuma, what is created is an anime with a bunch of fun, well animated gags with the occasional battle here and there to show off the animation as well as move the plot/introduce new characters. There is never really any real progression in the characters nor any crazy or particularly important changes in the plot, but I found this to be a good thing, and made for a show that was very very easy to watch and just enjoy without too much thinking and in that sense reminded me of Fumoffu!, both shows having a very high potential replay value.\n

Kono Suba, oh how much fun you've been.  I had a really hard time rating this show, as a parody changes the dynamic for story and characters.  KonoSuba almost tries to revel in how much of an anti-story it is, in fact.  Let's break it down and see where this show ends up:
Story (7/10) - So out of the gate we already have a difficult category.  The story is rather bare-bones in KonoSuba and based on an classic generic "trapped in a video game world" setup.  There isn't necessarily a whole lot of world building, and it doesn't even reallymove anywhere.  For most shows, this would be a huge hindrance to the story, but KonoSuba's parody-like nature changes the meaning behind it all.  KonoSuba isn't meant to tell a grand story of danger and adventure, it is meant to mock the tropes it is built on and the glory of the hero's journey.  The fact that the story can be at times episodic and not necessarily lead anywhere is the whole point.  The life of an adventurer isn't always straightforward, often times your journey meanders and you lose your way and even get stalled.  The story ends up providing a serviceable backdrop for our characters to act out their shenanigans, and at least a bit of a direction and progression for the characters.  It provides plenty of room for gags and insane happen-stance, without being bogged down by some grand message.  It gives the characters a great canvas to paint on and interesting colours to choose from.  As a result it is a good story as far as parodies go, not anything spectacular, but a solid base to expand on.


Art (6/10) - Art was certainly this shows weakest point, but as with the story, that isn't always as straightforward as it seems.  Many times the simpler and "derpy" animation actually worked to the benefit of the show, enhancing the silliness of reaction faces and greatly exaggerating the characters at their worst and best.  And despite the occasional poor instance of art, the show did have its moments of brilliance, especially when it came to characters casting magical abilities.  The character designs themselves were solid and enjoyable to see.  They felt very warm and comforting at times and Megumin was just outright adorable!  For any other show this score would have been below average due to some severe drops in animation quality, a 3-4 out of 10; however, because it works so well with the theme and style of the show, be it intentional or not by DEEN, and because I was quite partial to the character designs, it gets a respectable 6/10 for it.


Sound (8/10) - The sound in this show was fairly strong.  The opening and ending songs were fantastic and exceptionally comfy and I always enjoyed hearing them at the end of a long and tiring day.  The music throughout the show itself was rather uninspired, repetitive, and minimal, so I have to dock a point for missed potential there.  Most importantly though, for a parody to work well in anime, the Voice Acting is absolutely key to success, and the VA work for KonoSuba delivered.  Sora Amamiya absolutely nailed crybaby Aqua, and newcomer Rie Takahashi was excellent as Megumin, really lending that Chuuni goodness and gravitas Megumin required in her speeches while keeping her down to earth and adorable the rest of the time.  Jun Fukushima really played a good Kazuma as well, providing the perfect amount of snark and timing needed for the role.  The supporting cast was also fairly good, especially the girls in the Succubus den, but there were times where they weren't up to par, rare times.  Had the sound been filled out a bit more, this could very easily have been a 9 though.


Characters (9/10) - The characters in this show were absolutely mint.  They were fantastic in every sense of the word.  Aqua was so good as an annoying pain in the ass that I somehow couldn't help but feel some platonic affection towards, which is some kind of magic in and of itself.  Megumin was so, so adorable and you could really see her fluctuation in confidence despite the show she would put on.  Darkness grew a little bit stale at parts, but was nonetheless a presence on the screen when desired. Kazuma was just a fantastic sarcastic jerk, and even all of the side cast where generally very interesting.  All their fun background expressions, all the interesting character designs, and all of the fun interactions of the characters were just so fresh feeling.  I could't help but walk away from every episode feeling attached to these characters in some way or another.  You didn't necessarily see them grow a whole lot, but that isn't the point of this show.  They weren't necessarily there to change themselves throughout the story, even though they did to a small degree, they were there to engage you.  I think they absolutely succeeded in that regard nearly from enthusiasm alone!


Enjoyment (10/10) - By far the easiest category to rate.  If I could give this show an 11 for enjoyment, I would, because it was so much fun.  Very rarely did I find myself bored in this show.  Nearly all of the jokes landed, and I just had a smile plastered across my face for every episode.  I couldn't help but get invested in our pathetic quartet of heroes and really enjoyed watching them grow as a group rather than just individuals.  Their mutual camaraderie and affection was something truly missing from a lot of shows, even despite each of their faults.  At times it really felt like I was just watching a group of my idiot friends fail miserably at an MMO dungeon, and I loved every second of it.


So finally we come to my overall impressions of the show and it's impressive score of 8 out of 10.  The best way I can think to compare KonoSuba is to mention another favourite comedy of mine "The Devil is a Part-Timer".  Both shows nail their respective comedic parts, but Devil does it with a bit more polished animation and story depth.  KonoSuba is significantly weaker in this regard, but there's one thing KonoSuba has going for it that Devil just doesn't come close to: unbridled enthusiasm.  Yeah, KonoSuba didn't have the best art or even the makings of a well-defined story, but it had so much heart and spirit that I couldn't help but fall in love with it.  It isn't quite a 9/10 show, but I really, really wish I could have given it such a score because of how much fun I had watching it.  It is one of the most genuinely endearing comedy shows I've seen, and I greatly look forward to more material from it.

I might as well join the influx of people reviewing Konosuba immediately after it finishes airing.
Konosuba took me by surprise, I was not expecting an actually funny show from something that reads: Studio deen, light novel, and has a premise that sounds exactly like generic otaku empowerment fantasy. Turns out it's basically a parody of the "stuck in a video game" genre.
-Presentation (sound & visuals)
There's nothing for me to really complain about, this show has some obvious CG in it which still didn't really look out of place to me. As for music, I found the OP and ED pretty catchy, the rest of thesoundtrack was mostly forgettable though.\n\n
-Characters\n
Everyone from the villains to the main cast is a complete derp, and that's a big part of what makes this show so funny.\n
While the cast does have nice interaction and some funny quirks, I would've liked to see some more actual character development.\n
Every character would at first glance fit some archetype, but it quickly becomes apparent \n
there's a bit more going on.\n\n
-Story\n
Konosuba is a very episodic anime which will likely never actually have an actual ending.\n
The series starts off strong, constantly bringing new jokes to the table and builds up the rest of the story. As the sory progresses it starts to be carried by the new characters introduced every episode, after which I felt like I had seen basically everything that the show has to offer, but towards the end it got better for me.\n
And speaking of the end, I'm not sure if episode 9 could be considered filler because it's basically a fan service episode and mostly pointless otherwise.\n
Also second season announced (woo!).\n\n
-Conclusion\n
Konosuba is so far the best anime I have watched this season, though Shouwa Genroku Rakugo Shinjuu might replace it once I actually start watching it.\n
Shows like SAO and Danmachi make Konosuba more relevant, but it could stand by itself even if those shows never aired.\n
You might have problems liking this show, if the humor is just not your type, if you really dislike \n
fan service or you just don't like episodic anime that much.\n
Otherwise I would say it's a worthwhile watch.

After the releases of such shows like Sword Art Online and Log Horizon, many isekai (trapped in another world) anime have come and go throughout the recent years. One of these anime is a little comedy show known as "Kono Subarashii Sekai ni Shukufuku wo!" (God's Blessing on This Wonderful World!) aka Konosuba for short. This is probably if not, the best comedy anime to come out in recent years.
STORY: 7/10
After dying in a pathetic death, a NEET named Kazuma gets transported to a fantasy world along with the goddess Aqua. Together along with a mage called Megumin and a knight called Darkness go onmisadventures in the new world. With the new wave of isekai shows, the story can be a bit unoriginal. It is quite plain, almost to the fact that it sounds boring. The episodes can also very episodic, which means a new adventure for nearly every single episode. However, this is what makes Konosuba, well, Konosuba. It is plain, simple, yet it's absolutely hilarious. The comedy is gold and is very enjoyable. Konosuba is probably an anime homage to western cartoons and sitcoms which are known for their comedy. The biggest problem with the story is that it only has 10 episodes to tell the story. Only 10 freaking episodes to tell the whole story!


CAST: 9/10

This show has probably one of the most comedic cast of characters I've ever seen. The main characters at first looks like your average female harem cast with every anime cliche you can find. But there are more to them than meets the eye. Starting with Kazuma, despite looking like your average light novel MC, he plays as the straight/sane person of the group contrasting to the insane girls. Aqua is a spoiled brat that can be annoying at times, but she is one of the few who is funny and enjoyable. Darkness looks like the heroic type of character, but she is a total masochist who enjoys a lot of pain through fighting. Rounding of the MCs is the best girl Megumin, a loli chunnibiyo known for her explosion magic and is the most mesmerizing character in the whole series. The supporting cast can be either memorable or forgettable depending on your taste. Basically most of the characters are destroyed cliches, and that's what makes them memorable and fun.


ANIMATION: 7/10

Konosuba was produced by Studio Deen. I've seen clips of their shows like Higurashi and to be honest, their animation can be somewhat average. The same can be said to Konosuba. But much like the story, it may be plain, yet it's very hilarious. At times it can get a bit cartoonish just for laughs, but it is one of the few anime that does it right. The show is also very colorful and it clearly matches the style of the show. This makes the characters look more interesting, unique and fun. The setting however, can be either unique or just plain simple, like the whole town itself is pretty much like every fantasy anime out there. 


MUSIC: 9/10

The OP (Fantastic Dreamer by Machico) may sound like your average Jpop opening but when you watch it, it is very fun and hilarious to watch. The ED (Little Adventurer by Aqua, Megumin and Darkness) is very plain and mellow, yet very nice and calming to listen after watching the craziness of the characters. It is not often for an anime to have a western country/folk song for their OP or ED. In fact, Konosuba may be the only anime that has one. 


VOICE ACTING: 10/10

The biggest standout of the anime is the voice acting. Along with a similar anime called ReZero, Konosuba was one of the first subbed anime I've watched (since I prefer watching dubs and please don't kill me or anything). The voices fit perfectly with the characters. Like Sora Amamiya (known in Akame ga Kill and Tokyo Ghoul) who's very hilarious as Aqua, Ai Kayano (known in No Game No Life and Anohana) who suprisingly gives a deep voice as Darkness, and of course Rie Takahashi (known in ReZero) as everyone's favorite waifu Megumin. Will I see this show dubbed in the future? Who knows? I might not watch it dubbed at all since the Japanese is already too good.


OVERALL: 9/10

Konosuba may not be a masterpiece, but it is still a fun, lighthearted, very entertaining show. With memorable characters, colorful animation and lots of outstanding slapstick comedy, Konosuba is definitely worth the watch and is indeed one of the best anime in 2016.


PROS:

+ One of the best isekai shows out there

+ It destroys character cliches making the cast very memorable

+ Animation is very bright and colorful

+ A fun opening and a unique ending song 

+ Voice acting is spot on

+ The comedy, just the comedy


CONS:

- The story is too plain and may turn off viewers

- Animation at times can be a bit meh

- The supporting cast is mostly forgotten

- If this was dubbed then it may not be good as the sub

- How many isekai shows are there!? 

- And come on, only 10 episodes!?


Story: 7/10

Animation: 7/10

Sound : 9/10

Character: 9/10

Enjoyment: 10/10

Overall: 9/10


Also, thank Aqua for a second season since 10 episodes ain't enough!

The post SAO era of anime saw a huge spike in high fantasy shows with an MMO setting, while most of them are of a similar ilk with copy-and-paste plot and characters, Konosuba managed to strike at a comedy niche that made it stood out from the crowd.
You can expect the usual mix of stereotypes and plot clichés commonly associated with the genre, but instead of embracing them with open arms, Konosuba mocks them at every opportunity with witty writing to boot. Instead of an intricate plot with extensive lore, we were treated to the daily struggles of lowly adventurers. Instead of a looming senseof fate and destiny, we were treated with kill quests of giant toads and magical cabbages. Instead of a goody-two-shoes protagonist, we were treated to an egotistical shut-in that’s mostly out for himself, introduced in the humblest manner possible.


The characters were well designed and written, each member of the main party were peculiar in their own ways with various eccentricities. Discussing them here might spoil the plot so I will refrain from going into detail, but Kazuma was definitely one of the best protagonist I’ve seen as of late, while Megumin was memorable with her chuuni aesthetics and obsessive passion of “magic”.


Art is brilliant for the most part, there were little reuse of frames besides a few seconds of guild announcements and townsfolk dashing for shelters. Animation is smooth and expressive, close-in shots of characters were often detailed and fitting. The spell sequences especially looked the part with no expanses spared, I was glad that the same consistent level of quality was kept throughout the entire show.


If I had to nitpick, I would say 10 episodes were too short for the show’s own good. Granted that it had to be done for prevent a single gag from being overly drawn, among other budget related reasons. However some small parts were cut from the light novels, namely the introduction of Wiz, which inevitably damaged the shows pacing at times. The musical scores were a tad underwhelming too, none of the tracks were memorable or impressive, though the OP and ED were adorable and appropriate.


Without a doubt, this show was a highlight of 2016 and a must see. I have enjoyed the entirety of it, every episode from start to finish. It is also one of those shows that’s highly rewatchable, the type that you can leave running every other month and steal a peek while you’re busy doing stuff. Seriously, you should stop reading this and watch it already.

I actually really liked KonoSuba. Yes, it isn't the most hilarious, unique, or the wittiest show around, but it does what it is supposed to and with aplomb. Barring a few pacing issues and occasionally grating character design problems, this is indeed a really good show that is worth your time if you're looking for a show that will give you some good laughs with some entertaining characters and a pretty decent magical/game-world setting.
The plot synopsis gives barely anything away about what you as a viewer are about to experience. The introductory episode actually sets the tone perfectly for the rest of the series asyou're exposed to the rather unique character interactions that occur in this anime. I'd go so far as to say that if you don't like the first episode, you most likely won't enjoy the rest of this series at all. However, if you do at least think it is decent, prepare for more laughs along the way. There are some truly hilarious characters in this story which are complete parodies of their counterparts in other animes and RPG games. Their strengths and weaknesses truly work together in hilarious fashion which makes for much of the entertainment factor of this show. It does get a little repetitive towards the end of the season, but that's also where the pacing issues occur, so more on that later.


KonoSuba looks fairly decent, and the characters sound as funny as you would expect them to. The facial expressions that people make particularly appeal to me and often remind me of Nichijou's funny reaction faces. Of course, the two aren't all that similar, but their method of nailing reactions (that ordinary people like you or I would have) certainly is. The opening song, while decent, is rather forgettable. I did like the ending track and I've been learning how to play it on the guitar, but it doesn't really seem to have any connection to the show itself, unless it is attempting to appeal to the more Slice of Life elements of KonoSuba. The animations aren't exactly that great but the magical special effects are amazingly spectacular. The difference can be a bit jarring at times, but I suppose I'll take this positive for what it is. It also cements Megumi as the best girl.


My main issues with KonoSuba become prevalent towards the end of the season. First off, why on earth does this have only 10 episodes? A second season was announced at the end of episode 10, so clearly there isn't a dearth of - source material to adapt, funding for more episodes, or popularity for that matter. This show could've benefited GREATLY from even a couple more episodes (to hit 12-13) because around episode 8, there is a random time skip where a whole story arc is left out which can be extremely confusing to figure out at first. I actually had to go back and make sure I hadn't accidentally skipped any episodes. The show does do a decent job of filling the viewer in on what has been missed, but this was totally avoidable and breaks the flow of the anime for me, which is when I get distracted and begin noticing more flaws. Flaws such as the repetition of character-related jokes which were hilarious at first, but become less so once you keep seeing/hearing them over and over again. There are some character development issues as well and one can only hope that the second season will sort this out. Other than that, the main character himself is rather well done and quite relateable. He isn't a typical shut-in, goody-two shoes, or a pushover for that matter, and you can feel his frustration as he has to deal with these useless companions of his. He can be a complete dick towards them at times, but this is more out of exasperation than anything. Which makes him a main character with his unique own personality, and that I commend.


In conclusion, I would recommend KonoSuba to you if the thought of a comedy with action, slice-of-life, and game-world (SAO, Log Horizon style) elements interests you. KonoSuba knows what it is and doesn't try to do any more or any less than you'd come to expect from it (other than a few minor gripes mentioned above) and I genuinely enjoyed this show more than I expected to. It's definitely one of the better executed comedies out there. It actually has an okay plot that goes somewhere and moves things along, too. I'd rate this a 7.8/10, rounded off to 8/10. Hope this helps you decide!

This Anime was amazing check my complete review on 

http://baberitang.blogspot.co.id/2017/03/review-anime-konosuba-comedy-ecchi.html

[scroll to the bottom for a summary]
If there's one thing KonoSuba is, it's funny.
If you're looking for plot, character development or any sort of progression do not watch this show. Stop reading and move on. On the contrary if you want something funny, light-hearted and not too serious then this is probably exactly what you're looking for.
In recent years there's been a bit of a focus on MMO themed shows and I really appreciate that the producers have tried something different. It's not the same regurgitated content you might expect; instead it's wacky, over the top and doesn't even try to adhere to any ofthe standard MMO tropes. I am perfectly ok with this.


Its biggest asset however is also its biggest downfall. There's a fine line between comedy and stupidity and KonoSuba crosses it ever so slightly. From a general point of view the show suffers from extreme repetition. The same humour is applied throughout and doesn't change. This exhausts its comedic value, making it a little dull and predictable towards the end. Furthermore, past the half way point there's virtually no progression whatsoever. Combining these points kind of makes you wonder what the whole point of watching it was.


From a more personal perspective, I think that some of the characters were far too over the top and as a result made them seem stupid and unlikable. Though this is just preference based on my dislike of severely unrealistic characters it's still a valid point to bring up. 


Character development is also an issue. Considering the comedic nature of the show I suppose it's not too pressing but the repetitiveness of events + interactions limits any sort of meaningful development.


[Summary]


The fact that KonoSuba has an average score above 8 genuinely confuses me. While I appreciate the producers tried to do something different with the MMO genre they've executed it really poorly. It's funny to an extent but there's nothing else to it. The comedy continually repeats itself to the point where it's not amusing anymore and there is zero progression of any kind. Even comedy shows have to have some level of plot progression and character development, even if it's not very much. Kobato., for example, is a comedy with a nice story and lots of development (see here http://myanimelist.net/anime/5678/Kobato.).


If you have any comments/criticisms, please leave me a message or a profile comment as it will help me to write better reviews in the future. Thank you for reading.
