If your reading this I can only recommend you to watch this anime you will not be disappointed.\n\n
In fact you will laugh to tears.

This anime defies the simple plans most other adventure anime have. This anime is not your average protagonist gets special power and lots of girls loving him anime. The very purpose of this anime is too be more realistic and go the opposite direction of regular adventure and harem anime.  Though this may sound like a disaster, it is everything you would want: funny and lovable characters, humorous storyline, and many relatable scenes. "But I still want some action going on between the protagonist and the girls (if you know what I mean)" you might be thinking. Well, have no fear for there aresome scenes that can satisfy your hunger more than a snickers can (especially in one of the OVAs). Think of this anime as a near perfect balance of everything you wanted: romance, comedy, adventure, and action. Overall, this anime definitely gets a 10/10 from me and I'm pretty sure you're gonna give it the same rating after watching it.\n\n

Story - At first I thought it was generic, but seeing the anime and the light novels I can tell the lore is pretty cool too. full of references to DD and other old rpg games.
Art- I don't have nothing to complain here, I'm totally a fanboy and use some scenes from the anime as wallpapers
Sound - The opening it's great, really great. But the trophy goes to the ED song, where the MC companions sing together a rather beatiful and chilling song, I lost the count of how many times I went to the youtube to hear it, this coming from a guy thatnever care much about the soundtrack. 


Character- MC hates cliches and won't hesitate in kicking a woman, his companions are crazy powerful women making him the weakest in raw strength ( again, not cliche ). 

                   The other 3 companions are  stupid, crazy or Sadomasochistic and will make his life hard despite his great luck.


Enjoyment- Really, I already watched this anime 5 times, and read the light novel twice, there is like 15 light novels to read. it's really funny, and you end up loving the character despite their flaws.

I can finally say that i did watched this show so i can properly trash on it like crazy without holding back. To be completely honest? I expected for this show to be average so i could go with "meh, its a fine show".
The world and the story: The world of Konosuba is pretty interesting for being a "gaming" world, it doesnt do anything new (i don't think you have to flip the table like crazy and create something drastically unique to have a quality product) and while the start is incredibly cliche (despite the show trying to poke fun at cliches) it picks upfast towards trying to show off something original.

Why are some medics laughing when someone is dying though?


Art: It's fine but there is a TON of fanservice. I wouldnt complain if there wasnt so much or if the fanservice was slightly necesary but that's not the case. The fanservice is not necesary 90% of the time.


The op and ending are so forgetable and i'm saying this just after finishing an episode. A bunch of VA didnt seemed to fit the character at all like Aqua.


Characters: Kazuma was surprisingly entertaining most of the time but his comedy sometimes relied into poking fun at cliches and tropes. I like parody but in order to make a good parody you have to make something funny, something with quality or something entertaining enough to turn your head back and have some harmless laughter at whatever is being made fun of. 

Konosuba tries incredibly hard to be a parody but the show in itself is so incredibly boring that this backfires greatly. It's like a terrible soccer player taunting professional players and not being able to even make some proper passes.

The rest of the cast is boring and plain (Darkness being the only exception). Making one dimensional characters is not a bad thing, they have the ability to get character development, they can be funny if handled properly and they can make for amazing moments. Konosuba doesnt do any of this. The characters simply are there and after their initial impression they wont move too much or show off any redeemable qualities.

Also there is something wrong when your one dimensional characters try to make fun about a new one dimensional character that is being presented. You can deduce that yourself.

Again the show tries really hard to convince you that this band of people are unprepared and pathetic when they are not. They are not weak, they are crazy powerful and incredibly talented (that's also another cliche/trope...).


As for the fun you will have seeing the show. The selling point and argument of all the fans of the show i talked with was "I know it looks stupid but its really funny" "It's  good comedy" or something along those lines.

On the second episode the MC was waving around the underwears of a girl like a flag. 

That was so funny! (sarcasm).

The jokes in Konosuba aren't long or properly constructed. The level of comedy is almost at Pop Team Epic level of terribleness (but not crazyness) but PTE is aware of this.

Konosuba is not, a bunch of jokes are thrown here and there but aside from chuckling a little at the second episode there wasnt a moment of the show that was remotely funny.

My internal fan tried really hard to overlook the flaws my critical side was throwing at this show, desperately trying to grasp or grab something in the show that was worthwhile. 

Something that deserved praised, something entertaining, something DECENT.

There was nothing.

Kono Subarashii Sekai ni Shukufuku wo, also known as KonoSuba for short, probably ended up to be a big surprise for many. By judging the key visual, one might expect a generic trapped-in-a-videogame type anime, however it is anything but. An anime about a group of misfits who can’t decide what their true goal is couldn’t be more entertaining! It’s funny, wacky, and even lewd at times. This anime is for both people who love trapped-in-a-videogame type anime, and those who hate is too because it parodies those genres. 
~{Story}~
The premise is pretty similar to most anime of the same type; the main character choosesto go to an MMO-type game world and tries to beat that game with a group of companions. However, KonoSuba breaks away from those clichés pretty quickly. What first started as a party working together to try to beat the game, quickly turned out to be a party that’s too lazy to do such tasks and is better off doing the simple work. KonoSuba knows very well that you can’t take its plot seriously, so it spends more time on parodying it. And those who are familiar with MMORPGs should find some of the writing funny because it pokes fun at that genre. The anime consistently compares itself to an average anime of the same genre and shows to us how different it is for the better. The story really doesn’t go anywhere, mainly because it uses a slice-of-life/episodic format. The main goal was about defeating the Demon King in order to escape this world, but the story quickly stops caring less about that, which isn’t bad by any means since watching the main cast fool around is much more entertaining. 

Story: 7.5/10


~{Presentation}~

Konosuba cares about its comedy more than anything, and they spend the most time on that compared to anything else. And its comedy is pretty damn good! It doesn’t even need to rely on it comedic situations or humorous dialogues; as long as we see the main cast interacting with each other, it’s entertaining enough. Konosuba is a slice-of-life, even if it’s not mentioned as one. The anime is about a group of misfits that “work together” to “solve problems”. The first two episodes aren’t as funny as the rest of the anime though, so it might take a little bit of time to like it. But once the comedy gets good, it stays good. The comedy for the most part stays consistent after the third episode mark. They even parodied death flags! There are some fanservice here and there but they’re not too distracting (as a matter of a fact, some of it is pretty entertaining and fun). 

Presentation: 9/10


~{Character}~

The best thing about KonoSuba is its characters. Even if the anime had nothing but the main cast fooling around and interacting with each other, it’ll still be very entertaining. Kazuma, who is the protagonist of the series, starts off in a cliché way. He’s an otaku who ends up dying and is given the offer to go to an alternate game world, and he agrees. But he quickly proves to a hilarious, apathetic (at times), and sometimes an *ssh*le of a protagonist. He’ll take the easy way for every situation and his reactions to comedic situations are some of the best I’ve seen, even good enough to be compared to Nichijou and Gintama. Aqua, a goddess who got trapped in this world with Kazuma, is a pretty funny character, although she ends up being the weaker character out of them all, mainly because she’s the most normal out of the girls. Then there’s Megumin, a girl who has a fetish for explosions, however she wastes all her energy in one explosion that she ends up being useless for the day. She’s a hilarious character and she performs well in comedic situations. Lastly, there’s Darkness, a masochist that might be very strong, but all her attacks misses. Her masochism never gets boring as it never feels repetitive. 

Character: 9.5/10


~{Art}~, 

The art of this series is the weakest part of KonoSuba, as for the most part it’s not very appealing. The backgrounds are done well, but the architectures lack detailing. The character designs aren’t also very good. The faces of characters at times looks very cruddy and messy, and though some may say that it adds to the humor, it really just feels distracting. Some background characters really look copy and pasted. Hell, even the main cast looks like that too. Aqua and Darkness’s facial structure is exactly the same. If you just change their hair, they’ll look like twin sisters. However, the art isn’t completely terrible because it is still watchable. The costume design for the main cast is pretty good, and so it the world design too. 

Art: 6/10


~{Animation}~

Even though the art is almost mediocre, the animations aren’t that bad. The animations are definitely better than the art. During action scenes, it’s pretty well animated. Character movements are also pretty well done. Even the most unnecessary things, such as the main cast eating, is done very well. However there are points where it feels like a slideshow as some scenes aren’t animated, but instead it’s just a still picture, but those are just rare occasions. Also, facial expressions aren’t that well animated either as the cruddy art prevents a proper fluidity in the facial animations. But hey, at least the explosions look good! Also, the use of CG at the end for the monster was decent.

Animation: 7.5/10


~{Voice Acting}~

The voice acting is what makes the comedy special. The cast of seiyuu do a great job in their roles, even though most of them are pretty new to the industry. Fukushima Jun does Kazuma fantastically. Even though Fukushima hasn’t done much roles yet, he does an excellent job with his comic timing here. The over-the-top reactions to comedic situations was really well done. Amamiya Sora, who is a relatively new, yet highly loved seiyuu, does Aqua perfectly too. She manages to make the character look confident, whiny, and bossy whenever needed. Takahashi Rie, who is very new and inexperienced, does an outstanding job too as she manages to make Megumin look pretentious and overly confident, and pathetic and lazy at the same time. Lastly, Kayano Ai, who is probably the most experienced seiyuu of the bunch, does a spectacular job as Darkness (as expected). It sounded like she had real fun with her role, as she manages to make her sound confident and weak at the same time. She does the masochist parts very well (too well actually). There are some other well-known seiyuu that do supporting roles, such as, Eguchi Takuya and Horie Yui, and they do a fine job at what they have to do.

Voice Acting: 9.5/10


~{Music}~

The music probably isn’t the best part about this anime. The OP, “fantastic dreamer”, is simply okay. It not as catchy as it should be. The ED, “Chiisana Boukensha”, though isn’t that great, it does create some irony as it’s very peaceful sounding, but the anime is anything but. It was a smart decision to use an ED like this for and anime like this. The background music used for KonoSuba isn’t anything too special. Sometimes It feel misplaced, other times, it just feels boring. For most of the time, generic fantasy music is used, which is pretty disappointing. The placement of the OP in the last episode wasn’t the best idea either. 

Music: 6.5/10


~{Enjoyment}~

KonoSuba ended up to be a blast to watch. Even with lackluster art and music, the comedy stood out well. Relying on its characters more than anything, it manages to be enjoyable because of how well written these characters are. Starting from episode 3, I ended up laughing more than not. The humor ended up to be very consistent. Even the action scenes, particularly the action in the last episode, was enjoyable too. And I couldn’t be happier than it got a second season. The comedy may be subjective, but it might click with most people. 

Enjoyment: 9/10


KonoSuba was one of the biggest surprises of the season for sure. The key visuals don’t do justice at all. What first seemed as a cliché anime turned out to be parodying those genres. The characters ended up being lovable and voice acting done for them was fantastic too. This is Studio Deen’s best anime in a long, long time and consistency in writing shows promise in the studio’s future. And the fact that there’s a second season (and an OVA) made the anime look better. If you want some laughs and silliness, KonoSuba is perfect for you! Now time to wait for that second season! 


+ Fantastic characters with fantastic comic timing. 

+ Hilariously written, with comedy being mostly consistent throughout. 

+ The seiyuu cast, though mostly inexperienced, do a fine job in their roles

+ Tackles clichés of the same genre by parodying it. 

- Art is lackluster and cruddy at times. 

- Background music feels generic and felt misplaced during some occasions. 


Overall: 8.1/10

(This review has been adapted from my blog/reddit thread. Spoilers ahead!)
That night, as I started to drift off to sleep, my brain spoke to me. You forgot to brush your teeth. Gross, dude. I got up, half-groggy, and started to make my way to the bathroom. I was unfamiliar with the room’s layout, and it was dark, so I fumbled and felt for the door.
Once inside, I turned on the lights and began to brush my teeth. My eyes weren’t open, and I was barely conscious. Both of which made the sound of a door opening behind me that much more nerve-racking.
When I looked inthe mirror, I saw my father sitting on the toilet in the bathroom closet. I stared at him, dumbfounded, wondering what in the world he was doing.


My father only said a single word: “Hellooooo!”


I laughed so hard, toothpaste sprayed across the counter. My father started to laugh uncontrollably, too. Our combined laughter woke up my mother and my two siblings. Upon seeing me foaming at the mouth and leaning over the sink, and John squatting on the john, they couldn’t help but laugh as well. It was a happy beginning to a truly happy vacation.


I don’t fully know what prompted my father to push open his door and say hi, but his ridiculous decision led to comedy genius. Thankfully for KonoSuba, it likewise made the right decisions.


STORY


KonoSuba starts off innocently enough. Kazuma, a boy who basically keeps to himself, one day saves the life of another from an oncoming vehicle, dying in her stead. But when he finds out that the vehicle was actually a slow-moving tractor, that he really died of shock, and that he wet himself in the process, the anime begins its comedic journey.


While this opening example hints at the show’s parody chops, it is not until Kazuma (and Aqua) get to the parallel world that it really becomes apparent. The looming threat of the Devil King has to wait while Kazuma digs a whole for some carpentry and Aqua parties (and vomits) the night away. A horse-filled stable, rather than a comfy hotel room, becomes the home for these “heroes.” Monsters, quests, and money are difficulties too large for them to handle.


This parodic approach seeps into nearly every part of the show. When Kazuma, Aqua, Megumin, and Darkness save the city, they earn millions in the local currency but have to pay millions and then some to fix it. Abilities are often overly useless, dangerous, and perverted. The villains are not as evil as one would normally believe.


As parody parades, KonoSuba avoids repetition. Often times, it introduces new characters and elements without using them again directly. For example, Chris the thief arrives to give Kazuma the “Steal” skill which only gets used for stealing panties, some cabbages, and the dullahan Verdia’s head.


An even better example is Kyouya. Around for a single episode, he is used to parody the “chosen hero” stereotype: the girls find him creepy, he loses to Kazuma, and his fabled sword gets sold for a quick buck.


And even when the anime does reuse specific elements, it twists the presentation through parody. Verdia reappears because the others didn’t go to fight him in the first place. Wiz, one of the “evil” generals, teaches Kazuma how to use “Drain Touch” which gets used later as a joke during the “kissing” scene. Kazuma’s second reincarnation goes against the rulebook.


The anime also uses references from earlier episodes as jokes for later. Kazuma suggests fighting giant toads again, which Megumin and Aqua object to, but Darkness wonders and wants to experience it. The townspeople wait for Kyouya, but he won’t be showing up because Kazuma ruined the guy’s life the episode prior. Megumin mentions that “crimson demons don’t go to the bathroom,” and, while at the mansion, the entire bathroom debacle occurs.


All of the jokes and the parody leave little room for a thematic presence. Not that KonoSuba needs to have one, but it does try to inject one idea regardless: Life in this new world is not as glamorous as Kazuma was led to believe.


Unfortunately, this appeal also represents one of the show’s only major weaknesses. In many of the episodes, Kazuma gives some (thought-only) variation about how much he hates “this wonderful world” (to use the anime’s title).


The final words of the season reflect this not-so-subtle direction well, but it’s episode seven that demonstrates why the idea is an issue.


Kazuma’s second afterlife scene, where he “complains” about the troubles he went through, adopts a sentimental tone that the anime actively avoids. It’s one of the only kindhearted moments in the entire season.


Indeed, this scene offers the other perspective. That maybe a silver lining exists around the various troubles he encountered. Yet the show rips that thought away when, once again, Kazuma laments that he “made the wrong choice” on getting brought back as the episode concludes.


Now, to be fair, this idea is part of the parody. I.e., poking fun at such an emotional moment fits the premise. But that still does not excuse the show’s inelegant handling of this centralized concept. Especially when its other elements are handled with more execution.


ANIMATION


KonoSuba’s artistic direction leads to a small debate.


On the one end, the anime’s singular setting keeps the show from branching out. In fact, the same area just outside of the town’s gate is visited four times: once with the cabbages, twice with Verdia, and once with Destroyer. It wouldn’t be much of a problem if the location itself was teeming with detail, but it’s just an unassuming, boring spot for action to occur. Almost as if the anime didn’t know where else to go.


Other backgrounds are likewise not as appealing. A snowy plain, a large lake, and a shot of the stables are certainly appropriate but devoid of creativity.


On the other end, the anime can prove itself. The inside of the local inn has patrons, bar maids, and other facets – such as light fixtures, wooden tables, and the nearby quest board – that make the building a hub of activity. Quaint shots of the city streets, accompanied by soft lighting, give the anime a homely feel, contrasting with Kazuma’s oft derision of the world. And the anime can visit different spots: the succubus brothel, their mansion, and Wiz’s store to name a few.


All of which says nothing of the minor details. Lips are sometimes fully drawn, eyes sparkle with intricacies, and clothes crinkle and crease. Added details that may not be expected but are certainly welcome.


The anime further proves its clout when one of its “negatives” ends up being a positive overall: roughness. Uneven lines, misplaced eyes, and wonky facial expressions are normally turn-offs, but, in KonoSuba’s case, this roughness in the art elevates the comedy and hence the appeal of the show itself.


Due to the unchanging location and the roughness, actual animation sees a lot of attention. Aqua’s eyes moving to see if the others are still watching her cry. Megumin going through some karate moves. Darkness unable to control her excitement at joining the party. Each an example of KonoSuba’s attention to animated detail.


Indeed, the show arguably diverts most of its animation resources into the different sexual bits. Luna, the big-busted quest-giver, always receives extra frames for her breasts. Chris, after her panties are stolen, grabs her crotch rather vigorously. And the leader of the succubus brothel moves, bends, and squishes in all the right places.


If nothing else, Megumin’s famous “Explosion!” sequences – with their colors, swirls, and galactic depiction – demonstrate that both its animation and art are nothing to scoff at.


The anime also plays with perspective. Kazuma running down a hallway in first-person view or Darkness getting really up in the audience’s face showcase different levels of cinematography.


But, without a doubt, the character designs are easily the best part of the art department.


Kazuma’s starting track suit fits the parody direction, and his later shoulder garb finally gives him a sense of heroism. Aqua’s looped hair, embroidered outfit, and revealing-yet-not-quite skirt envelops the goddess with an air of importance. Megumin’s large wizard hat, eyepatch, and mismatched leggings fit her chuunibyou antics splendidly. And Darkness’s long blonde hair, tough armor, and stunning figure highlight both her classiness as well as her sexiness.


Yet it’s their coloring and color symbolism that truly shines.


Kazuma’s black and green symbolizes his derisive attitude and “good luck.” Aqua’s blue and pink symbolizes her crybaby personality and “sweetness.” Megumin’s red and brown symbolizes her power and her “endurance.” And Darkness’s orange and white symbolizes her enthusiasm and “purity.”


As can be read, each character has a color associated with him or her that contrasts with what the audience normally perceives, heightening the parody and subconsciously adding to the overall level of comedy the show so regularly achieves.


CHARACTERS


While KonoSuba’s story and art are intriguing, its lovable troupe of characters make the anime into the comical romp it becomes. Namely, Kazuma, Aqua, Megumin, and Darkness are the champions of the series.


Starting with the girls and Aqua more specifically, she is initially pinned as a kindhearted goddess. Sending the deceased to better lives and using holy magic to heal others, she seems helpful and understanding.


But it quickly becomes apparent that she is not only rather mean but also rather annoying. She constantly cries for Kazuma’s help, and she either has powers that are impractical or overly detrimental.


In comedic terms, she’s a character that makes the audience feel superior. It’s fun to see her wailing about her snow buddy or about not wanting to teach others her type of magic because of how useless she manages to be. In other words, the audience feels as though they are always in a better position when compared to this crybaby.


Megumin is similar. She’s not rude like Aqua, but she is certainly not without her quirks. Chief among them being her chuunibyou persona. She speaks, dresses, and acts in a fantastical manner, giving her an air of silliness. Her silliness, however, is justified when she displays her immeasurable destructive power through the explosion magic she commands.


At least, it’s justified until before she unleashes her singular ability. For that’s all she can do. Literally. After using her one spell one time, she is essentially rendered inert, unable to move without the assistance of another.


Again, in comedic terms, she’s a character that makes the audience feel relief. Her character talks the talk and walks the walk. But when the explosion subsides and the dust settles, she, like Aqua, is useless and hence funny. In other words, she builds up emotion in the audience that is later released (in the form of laughter).


Perhaps obviously at this point, Darkness is similar, too. On the outside, she’s a beautiful woman whose determination to protect the people is laudable. But once one gets to know her, however, they realize that she’s a bit strange. She revels in the pain, the suffering that comes with said protection. To the point that it sexually arouses her. Plus, she cannot even hit stationary targets with her weapon. That’s how pitiful she is at wielding a sword.


Again (again), in comedic terms, she’s a character that makes the audience feel incongruous. Her immoral behavior and abysmal swordsmanship in no way befits a proud knight, and it’s this stark contrast that makes her useless and therefore funny. In other words, her unexpected characterization creates comedy.


Altogether, Aqua, Megumin, and Darkness each exemplify a different “brand” of humor. It’s what gives the anime so much comedy clout. The show relies on a unified motif of uselessness, but, by branching out into different forms of comedy, KonoSuba manages to appeal to many people.


As for Kazuma, he gets the brunt end of the stick. When he gets a new chance at another life, he discovers that it’s not much better than his old one. Indeed, it’s worse. A final goal so daunting that he chooses instead to accept his current fate. A set of situations so harrowing that he refuses to do anything even remotely dangerous. A group of friends so aggravating that it’s a wonder he makes it through the day in one piece.


Kazuma is fed up with all of these problems, taking it out on said friends. He berates Aqua for wasting all of their money. He chastises Megumin for her one-and-done approach. He harps on Darkness for her masochistic tendencies.


It’s understandable. Most people in his position would most likely have similar feelings. It’s human nature to complain when the going gets tough, when life hands one lemons, and any other related cliché.


For this reason, it makes Kazuma relatable and therefore likable. Where the rest of the town sees the girls as members of the best class roles and saviors of the city, the audience sympathizes with Kazuma and his mindset because they get to see what the arch-priest, the arch-wizard, and the crusader are actually like.


To be fair, the girls aren’t completely useless. Aqua brings water to those who need it, Megumin obliterates the competition, and Darkness boosts the morale of others. And it’s precisely for this reason that Kazuma’s constant negativity comes off as hilarious. In other words, since the audience knows that the girls can be useful, when they aren’t (which is most of the time), Kazuma’s scathing words are more than justified and therefore comedic.


Sadly, the anime does not give much more to their characters beyond their fleshed-out characterizations. Kazuma’s previous life, Aqua’s religious sect, Megumin’s own “race,” and Darkness’s rich family are alluded to but never shown.


Given the show’s shortened season (ten episodes as opposed to twelve or thirteen) and the show’s nearly pure focus on comedy, it may be unreasonable for one to expect the cast to have more of a background let alone development.


Even so, them lacking more to their characters leads to them relying on their shticks again and again. Aqua only ever cries, Megumin only ever yells out her catchphrase, Darkness only ever gets turned on, and Kazuma only ever speaks the (harsh) truth.


It can get repetitive, but, thankfully, their strong comedic roots keep this issue in check for the majority of the season.


SOUND


Arguably speaking, the single strongest aspect of KonoSuba is its ending track.


Titled “Chiisana Boukensha,” this ED is one of the best to ever grace the medium. The beat’s methodical calmness instills a sense of peace and elation. Aqua, Megumin, and Darkness sing both individually and in harmony, their voices both tranquil and sincere. And the country-farm tone – with its banjo, flute, drums, and other atmospheric instruments – captures the down-to-earth, everyday life that the lovable cast never gets to have. It’s a phenomenal track that deserves as much praise as possible. Now and for years to come.


While nothing else in the sound department comes close to the ED, the voice-acting performances are fantastic in their own right. Sora Amamiya as Aqua brings hilarity in droves with her crying, screams, and arrogant manner. Rie Takahashi as Megumin chants her way to “Explosion!” cuteness. And Ai Kayano as Darkness, with her impassioned speeches and seductive moans, provides attractiveness in more ways than one.


Jun Fukushima as Kazuma also deserves a shout-out. Mostly for his mean-spirited speaking. But he also introduces even more comedy with his occasional interjections. Responding with “Yes, I’m Kazuma” when the girls try to get his attention, asking “Really?” as they talked during dinner time, and getting in a “Bring it” as Wiz prepares to “suck” him made for some silly adlib moments that fit the anime more than well.


The original soundtrack is also praiseworthy, for while it does not have the same high level of execution as the ED and the voice acting, it’s not without its own strengths. The rap-like, ukulele track is both catchy and fun. The soft, simple piano piece makes those heartwarming moments that much warmer. And the individualized tracks for each character – Kazuma’s heroic tune, Aqua’s church choir, Megumin’s otherworldliness, and Darkness’s promiscuous ladies – add further to their overall characterizations.


Lastly (and perhaps least) sits the opening track. Guitar, chimes, and drums create an optimistic and lofty OP, taking a contrasting direction when compared to both its ED counterpart and the anime itself. The ending segment with the stepping violin gives the track a final flourish that gets the audience prepared for the comedy to come. It’s not exactly strong, but KonoSuba’s other sound offerings more than make up for the passable OP. (The ED alone covers it and then some.)


ENJOYMENT


I absolutely love this one.


And there’s a reason for that. It doesn’t always happen in an anime for me, but this one managed to achieve the ever elusive dream: I am fully a fan of each character.


For Kazuma, him speaking aloud his disapproval of the others was never tiring. Getting ready to punch Aqua for her deliberate attempt at sympathy. Telling Megumin to use a nearby vase to pee in. Forcing Darkness, without reproach, to lather him up in the bath hall. He’s a likable central protagonist through and through.


For Aqua, her overreactions had me laughing out loud. When she was excited to beat up Kazuma for him defending the “evil” succubus (Aqua’s eyes especially). When she bawled about needing money or help. When she acted like she didn’t want praise but actually did. She’s incredibly annoying yet insanely funny.


For Megumin, her chuunibyou behavior was always welcome. Her floating down a puddle of water to get closer to Darkness to give her a thumbs up. Her pretending to be dead in the snow. Her caressing her arch-wizard’s staff due to the drug-like addiction she has with explosions. She’s small in stature, but she left a large impression.


For Darkness, her attractiveness had me hooked. Getting pushed into the snow turned her on. When she smiled from embarrassment while admitting her faults in fighting. Her willing to protect her friends as the crusader she is. She’s sexy, interesting, and amazing.


Kazuma, Aqua, Megumin, and Darkness are just so much fun that it didn’t matter what they were doing on-screen. I knew I could count on them to make me laugh. And I know they will continue to do so when that second season eventually rolls around.


KonoSuba is a comedy adventure. With extremely hilarious characters, amazing sound-work, and parody for days, it’s a wonderful anime that nobody should be afraid to say “Hellooooo” to.


SUMMARY


Story: Good, an adventurous parody with smartly reused jokes and subtle in-narrative references, brought down by an overstated complaint about the world being too tough


Animation: Great, despite the unchanging location, positives like the comically rough art, the above average levels of actual animation, and the superb character designs are visually pleasing to see


Characters: Good, the main cast’s strong comedic roots are hampered by their overused shticks caused by there not being a whole lot more to their characters


Sound: Great, one of the best ED’s in the medium, fantastic voice-acting performances, and a nice OST overcome the passable OP


Enjoyment: Great, Kazuma, Aqua, Megumin, and Darkness are a downright awesome group of adventurers


Final Score: 9/10

Ive watched Konosuba around a year ago and I still feel the same way about it. The main character is really dumb and short. I feel like there is no plot. Every episode feels like a different story and it is going nowhere. The girls in the series I would rate average. The blue hair girl is really funny and would rate a 10 but it goes back down to a 2 because of her hair color. Im not one to judge someone buy their looks but I do not like this girl because of her blue hair. Blue is just not my favorite colorand never will be. The art of the story is okay I mean it is the art for any average anime not bad not good. The sounds were cool like the explosions from that loli or whatever. It was enjoying on the ecchi scenes but its only Tv-14 so im like whatever. If ur friend wants you to watch this dont.

This show really knows how to do comedy right. It plays around with cliches instead of becoming one, and the every dialogue feels like it's part of a skit ( there'a a lot of that Japanese "konto" style humour).
The premise is simple and funny enough that you don't have to think or wonder about (like you might with Overlord, Log Horizon, etc.), the characters are great, and you can see that the main thing the entire studio focused on was the humour. The drawing, the movements, the sound effects, the quickness of the witty replies, the voice acting, everything is centred around humour, and itWORKS.


I loved how Kazuma will reply to anyone calling him to "Yes, I'm Kazuma" RIGHT AFTER he gets called, and in quick, low volume addition that gets IGNORED by the caller. It's probably a common joke in high schools or comedy skits in Japan, but we get to see it in anime with fresh eyes.


Megumin's voice actor is simply amazing. Even in simple scenes she adds character. E.g. When Kazuma first meets her, he pulls on her fake eye-patch, and she shouts "Yame, yamero!!", but instead of just keeping it a monotone and upset shout, she adds this commanding, growling tone in the middle to kinda give it a "How dare you! How about you stop?!" feeling. Excellent!


It's a great comedy show, totally worth a 9/10.

Warning possible Spoilers:
Everyone get ready to hold onto your butts and shout EXPLOSION!!! because this is one hilarious adventure that you won't be forgetting anytime soon.
It starts out with Kazuma Satou dying from the most ridiculous death, then he meets Aqua a water goddess who gives him the option to go to a fantasy world to fight the Demon King, Kazuma takes Aqua with him, but finds out she is useless and he eventually meets other girls who are just as useless.
This is another one of those animes where it doesn't need a strong plot to make it good instead it relies on the mischiefsof the main characters and by God are these mischiefs hilarious, they take on random quests to earn money, but they always end mostly in failure because of how dysfunctional the team is which is actually a nice change from the many other heroic teams who get stronger over time whereas these guys just keep getting into more and more trouble, there were some points in the show where it actually got serious, but they still managed to make the situation so funny even when the characters are facing certain death.


The Characters were fantastic usually when you see a male character with multiple female characters you expect the Harem tag, but this time hell no each of these girls has something that completely impacts kazuma's actions like for example Aqua is a water Goddess, but everything she does is completely and utterly useless it's funny seeing her whine like a cry baby especially when she's being chased by giant frog's, then you have Megumin who is a magical loli girl who only likes casting one spell and that's EXPLOSIONS!!! however she can only use it once and it paralyses her body meaning she's completely useless for the rest of the fight and finally you have Lalatina who is a Crusader, but not just any ordinary Crusader she's a masochist Crusader and she can't even hit anything with her sword either so you can see how bad, but hilarious this combination is.

I loved it when these characters tried their absolute best just to earn a coin and the results were spectacular, I wish characters like these were more common because seeing the good guys mess up a lot is great entertainment.


I really liked the artstyle as it gave off a smooth look and the faces that the characters made when things went completely wrong is possibly one of the funniest things I have ever seen.


There is actually some battles in the anime, but because of how random and weird the main characters are they just turn the situation from serious to funny and they even manage to defeat the villains just by doing it in the stupidest way possible.


If you are looking for a Fantasy anime, but instead of having overpowered protagonist's you get the most dysfunctional team ever then you are set to have one hilarious roller coaster that will make you laugh till the very end

This is a funny and entertaining anime. 
The premise is similar Is It Wrong to Try to Pick Up Girls in a Dungeon? but more self-aware. More accurately, it is a parody of Is It Wrong to Try to Pick Up Girls in a Dungeon? and the dungeon-crawler/video game genre. The best part of this anime is that it is really funny. In fact, it’s one of the funniest animes I’ve seen in a while. 
Story: While the story isn’t exactly original, it’s well executed. I also like that it starts with a premise and sticks to it. This gives each episode a sense ofconsistency and allows one to get immersed. I will say a word of caution about the plot. It isn’t so much a story, rather it is more similar to the slice-of-life genre. The characters do have a goal and work towards it but it does take a back seat to daily life. The episodes focus more on the journey rather than the destination. If you like a story with a single, overarching conflict as the focus then you won’t enjoy this anime. Instead, what’s makes this amine great is the humor, the world it creates, it’s parodic nature, and the character’s interactions. I would say that the characters are another good aspect. The main character is a “fish out of water” which makes him really relatable. The other characters are not as deep as they would be in a drama, nor should they be. They have the perfect amount of depth to be both funny and interesting. It’s actually one of the few instances where the perfect balance is achieved. 


Animation/Sound: The animation is pretty good but where this anime shines is in the voice acting. It is fantastic. The voices have depth and range. They complement the character and the character’s situation perfectly. They are so good that they make the jokes even funnier.   


Overall, it’s funny and really worth watching.

Disclaimer: this counts as a review for both seasons and
so, a bunch of months ago i watched konosuba and was pretty disappointed considering the praise and popularity it had received and gave it a mid-5 mark. Still, i thought maybe i hadn't given it a fair chance considering i had binge watched the whole 20 episodes of both seasons in the last 10 hours of a 30 hour day. Sleep deprivation is not typically associated with sound judgement, so recently, i decided to rewatch it.  
Konosuba is a low-6. That's not much better.
There are 2 things i really like about Konosuba andi will lie about both of them. The first thing to mention are the excellent characters, Megumin being a mage who can only use Nuke magic and then fall-down is very funny, Darkness being a masochist who loves to take damage is very funny and Aqua being a god of tremendous power who is simply too stupid to use it is also very funny. Oh and Kazuma's an asshole. Guess that's somewhat funny too. Yeh, ok not really. the reason why this is a lie though is that now you have read those few lines you know about everything there is to know about those 4 main characters. darkness gets a bit of backstory in the first half of season 2 and that's it but except for that you don't learn more about the characters or see them change throughout the whole 20 episodes of the series.


The second good point (which is a lie, remember?) is the format. Konosuba follows a very simple format, each episode a different problem is brought before the party and they have to resolve it and in doing so they (mostly Aqua) fuck up in a way that will cause the next problem to arise later. this makes the series pretty bite-sized, one which you can drop and pick back up rather easily. Now, the lie is that a lot of episode are actually just filler. Like kazuma says: "hey guys, let's go kill some snow flakes" or "hey guys, let's go kill some lizards" and twenty minutes of real time later they come back having gained and lost nothing. 


now, now, this is a character driven full-comedy show, no matter what the one important thing is for the jokes to be funny. as long as the jokes are funny, nothing else really matters. And the jokes are funny! oh wait, that was another lie wasn't it?  


THE JOKES ARE FUNNY BUT I CAN COUNT THEM ON MY HANDS.

Kazuma's disrespectful, Kazuma's a pervert, Aqua is unlucky, Aqua is Stupid, Darkness is a masochist, Darkness can't hit anything, Megumin's likes weird names, Megumin loves explosions, Yun-yun is antisocial and the world of adventurers isn't all that dreamy. those are all the jokes. ALL OF THEM. there are a few genuinely funny things every now and then that aren't repeated into oblivion but overall the jokes for the main cast are always the same thing. over and over again. it gets tiring pretty fast.


i might be slightly exaggerating here, there were a few episodes that would have been mid-high-7 if they were to be judged alone. I'm thinking of S1E10, S2E4 and S2E5 in particular. i also really liked the verdas episode (and his character in general) and the joke that the eris currency suffers from inflation because eris pads her chest... hehe. that one's clever and subtle... i like it!  


now that the main complaints are out of the way, lightning round!: the music is rather unmemorable, with the ops and eds being just one level above that. The voice acting is actually really good but sometimes it doesn't match the animation, i'm thinking of that one scene in S1E9 where a guy is seen laughing while he just talks normally sound-wise. speaking of speaking, the mouths and facial features look kind of gross/misplaced/ deformed at times, some of those times it's the intended effect while others i can't help but feel like the makers fucked up. the art in general is generic and so is most of the character design outside the three main girls. i guess that shot of the hotspring town from above was pretty. that's about it


TL;DR:

Konosuba gets a low-6 for being bogged down by it's abusive plot/joke recycling as well as for its rather unimpressive technical prowesses. there are a few things to be caught in a rewatch so that makes it just about break through the ceiling and up to a mid-6 for both season.


Recommendations:

1. If you want a good character-driven comedy and won't mind a little side dish of SoL and Romance i would recommend Working!! over konosuba any day even if it means you lose a bit in the sexually-daring department.

2. If you're not willing to take the love-bullshit that Working!! will inevitably be serving i would recommend Hinamatsuri. there's more deep-feeling stuff but i think there's also a greater chance of getting your money's worth in the laugh department.

3. Finally, of course, i have to say it, if you're slowly crawling towards sleep deprivation, are maybe a bit drunk, and just want to have a mindless laugh while also probably wanting to destroy a good portion of your functioning neurons. Well there's only one anime it can be right? say it with me. *eyes shine red* *red filter applies* *image Jpgifies itself* THe ;b:phOne ANIme!!1!

It's been done to death. Fantasy RPG-themed show, hero is a former Earthling who is given a second shot at life but in a different world.
From the outset, you know this isn't like Re:Zero, because one of the first things the goddess guiding Kazuma to another world does is laugh herself silly at the circumstances around his death, and at the same time this scene gives you an idea of just how the dynamics of the characters are going to roll. After telling Kazuma he can take one amazing skill or object to his new life, she quickly becomes bored and busies herself with somechips.


So Kazuma does the natural thing and tells said goddess to come along as his chosen object.


If it isn't clear at this point, this is a parody of every RPG-themed anime that mercilessly makes fun of fantasy. Introducing the party... we have a NEET hero who is average at everything but luck and specializes in fighting dirty, an incredibly stupid monster magnet goddess (no one believes her) with great stats in everything but intelligence, a chuunibyou arch wizard who can cast the most powerful spell in the world (but only that spell, and only once per day), and a tank who can't hit anything and is a huge masochist (her actress is Ai Kayano, and honestly Grancrest would've been far more interesting if that other buxom blonde voiced by Kayano acted like Darkness). Taking this team into a raid in your typical RPG will naturally get them killed, so this party seldom leaves the starting town, and manages to defeat several mini-bosses largely through sheer luck. And yet, watching this party of misfits get themselves in the silliest situations is the single best running gag of the show.


The comedy is not unlike Monty Python and the Holy Grail or Red Dwarf: a series of loosely related comedic sketches, and the joke punch lines are often of the "yank the rug" type. Gags often involve a character getting denied what they want most, which is effective largely because you know from their personality or situation that they absolutely do not deserve it. Other gags involve the party getting in serious trouble because one or more members get carried away (and the show is quick to remind you that even the seemingly serious situations are jokes).


While the backgrounds are mainly bog-standard CG, and the character designs mainly designed for comic effect or titillation (because there's always that chauvinist who wants girls who are more boobs than brains high up in the production chain) more than anything, the special effects, mainly spells, are well-executed, and is a great setup to several jokes, whether it's Aqua getting slimed or Megumin throwing her only spell every day for a few months.


The character animations felt... cheap to me, as though the tween animators weren't given enough time to draw detailed motion and thus were forced to avoid drawing whole frames as much as possible. The result here is repetitive motions, heavy reliance on still or mostly-still frames (you can see this most prominently in dialogue-heavy scenes), and other shortcuts that were common back in the 1980s-1990s; juxtaposed with more detailed action scenes, this makes the animation look inconsistent or jerky. Sometimes this worked (usually involving a sobbing Aqua), but in general, it made the show look like a B cartoon. At the end of the day, all the CG in the world can't save bad animation.


The soundtrack evokes Nobuo Uematsu and other fantasy RPG composers just a bit (for obvious reasons), with just a little exaggeration in the epic "quest begin" and "quest complete" fanfares, and a mix of silly themes to help set the comedic stage. The opening theme is a good match to a slapstick-heavy sketch comedy show, and the ending theme eases you out of the episode; the intentional "cut off the character's letter" previews are also hilarious.


I'll close by pointing out the title animation with the characters swaying to the music is a good expression of the show itself: "We're all hopeless in some way or another, but we're having fun together, so that's cool."

For SAO fans and other people expecting a "serious dark virtual reality with a harem cast of characters", this show will disappoint. But for regular people who enjoy watching comedy that isn't serious, yep this one fits your description. This anime pretty much parodies everything the fantasy genre has to give you, it even pokes fun at a certain character from SAO, *cough cough guy who gets hit 50 times without dying*. Other then that overall its comedy is great and if your looking for an anime that isn't serious and will you cheer you up, you can go ahead and say hello to Konosuba.

I remember skipping over Konosuba S1 when it first came out due to being sick of the "Stuck in another world" genre the anime community has become well used to seeing by now. That was a mistake, one of my friends highly suggested I checked it out as it brought much more to the table than any other of these stuck in another world animes. See Konosuba takes this beautiful world and shows that just showing up to new world might not be as amazing as people make it out to be.
Kazuma, the main protagonist from start to end is one of the most likablemale protagonists I have ever seen in anime. Kazuma always manages to be such a likable character despite being one of the biggest jerks ever. He's such a depressing and rude guy yet THIS is what makes him such a lovable guy, Kazuma is never just given anything, they almost never succeed the first time and often end up having their spirits destroyed. Unlike other "stuck in another world" animes they have to constantly be working for what they want despite their many failures, yet they keep moving forward in attempt to get what they want.


The artwork is absolutely beautiful and is just straight up fun to look at. There's so much that goes into the artwork. For example, they try to never give the characters the same face twice. It would be much simpler have a set few faces to react to different situations. (happy, sad ,shocked etc) Constantly giving them new faces to react to scenarios really helps with the comedy factor, if they had the same few faces it would get stale seeing the same reaction whenever something funny happened. 


Konosuba really puts allot into their back round art, characters who they team talks to maybe once have their own design and unique personality, no one just feels like they're there just because they need characters to make the world look alive. Konosuba also has some of the nicest scenery I've ever seen, In epsiode 8 of S2 when the team arrives at the hot springs town we're treated to this beautiful view of the town and the landscape. This helps you connect to the town and makes you think that this town really is perfect before they reveal why this town may not just be as amazing as you'd think.


I most definitely recommend this anime to EVERYONE, 10% of this anime is just ripping on the "stuck in another world" genre and 90% of it is improving with it's beautiful visuals and comedy. Konosuba shows us that this genre can find success without always being depressing and super serious...

Overall:
This is a very well done comedy anime. There's not much of an overall story, but it doesn't really need one. It's funny and just plain fun to watch, without anything really to complain about. 
Score: 8/10
Story:
There isn't really a plot, honestly. Think sitcom. You're just watching a group of people as they do their thing. That said, "their thing" is both hilarious and strangely heartwarming, and I didn't really care about the lack of plot. I can't give this aspect a score above average, but it won't affect the overall rating because it didn't really affect the experience.
Score: 5/10
Art:
There wasn't anything to complain aboutwith the animation. The lack of choppiness and overall polish grants it one point above average, and although there was still some CGI, it was only used in scenes where it wouldn't look dumb. It actually ended up looking pretty alright when it was used, so that's another point above average.\n
Score: 7/10\n\n
Sound:\n
The intro and outro were pretty average. Not bad, but not particularly good. The music in general though did a great job of matching and enhancing the atmosphere of the other world, good for two points above average. What I really liked about the soundtrack in this anime though was the way each character had their own distinctive music. This was used to highlight which character "had the floor" at any given time, and was a nice touch for which I have to add another point.\n
Score: 8/10\n\n
Character:\n
What's weird about this department is that, even though I'm not really a huge fan of any of the characters individually, they make up one of my favorite groups. The chemistry between them is just perfect. The main character is one of my least favorite protagonists in anime - he's pretty much a scumbag - but the way he reacts to the antics of the other three and the way he compensates for each of their shortcomings is one of my favorite character dynamics in anime. It's just impeccably designed. \n
Score: 9/10\n\n
Enjoyment:\n
I had a blast watching this anime. It was funny, and it was fun. That's all there is to it.\n
Score: 9/10

We're going to explode it" (after reading this again it felt very badly written. I meant that I didn't like how there's a problem and they fix it 3 times in a row.
