If you're looking for a show with a deep and complex plot, this isn't it.
If you're looking for a show that takes it self seriously, it's definitely not this.
That comedy tag is quite justified, this is quite the parody show with just enough story and character development to make it more than a series of jokes.  On paper this show's recipe could easily have gone horrible wrong, but as it is they pretty much nailed it.
Oh, and this show is definitely in the "blatant sexual references" territory.
This should be spoiler free, though the character descriptions for Megumin and Darkness should be skipped if youwant to get the full facepalm value out of their introductions.


---

Story: 7

Character: 10


First up, our "hero" Kazuma is a text book Dangerously Genre Savvy character.  Which is actually allowed since he has a plausible in universe reason for having that knowledge.  A standard shut-in trope, he turns out to actually be the most useful character in most situations simply by being normal and thus capable of maintaining rational thought for more than 5 seconds.  He's kind of pathetic at times, but you have to feel sorry for him.

If you like a smart ass with dry wit, you'll like Kazuma.


Next we have Aqua.  I had a hard time putting my finger on exactly which trope she best fits but I'll go with Beware the Silly Ones.  Deities are supposed to be powerful, wise and all knowing, so go figure that Kazuma gets landed with one that's thick as two short planks and backfires almost as often as she lands an attack.  Obviously she also tends to forget to inform the party of her abilities until after everyone else has freaked out that said ability is necessary.


As an offensive mage we have Megumin, a character I can only imagine was created from taking the description "Black Mage Glass Cannon" and running with it.  She is the physical embodiment of "Go Big or Go Home", a character that solves every problem by turning in to a crater.  She's cute, in a constantly face palming kind of way.  She also seems to be sexually attracted to explosions.


And, to round out the party we have poor Darkness.  You might think she looks like some kind of Paladin, but you'd be wrong.  See she would have taken the book on how to be a Paladin and thrown it out the window, except she'd likely miss the window.  A literal meat shield most of the time, and entirely aware of it.  To offset the potential for her being pathetic she's also cute and mostly sane and reasonable.  Mostly.  She's stubborn and reckless.  She's also a perverted masochist... this might be handy for a meat shield if she didn't get so turned on by being beaten up.


Surrounding them is a cast of RPG tropes who some how don't come off as being two dimensional, opposing them are some bad guys that seem hilarious when they're not demonstrating genuine lethal capacity.


So, the story isn't outstanding, but it's not terrible either.  Really the complaint is more that it's so short, rather than that what there is of it is bad.  I figure this will improve when season 2 gets released.  The characters sell the show though.


---

Art: 8

Sound: 8


No real complaints on either count, just a few slightly off bits.

The art is solid even if it isn't classic masterpiece levels of eye candy, the effects look nice and there's not much in the way of blatantly reused footage that I noted.  They probably reused some environmental backgrounds, given the number of scenes that happened in the same core places, but I don't think you'll notice them unless you're specifically looking for them.  I'd give it a 9, but I think they had a little too much fun with some of the scantily clad characters.


Sound is similarly solid.  The themes are nice, though they don't quite seem to have gotten stuck in my head the way some have.  Nothing terrible is jumping out at me about the voice acting or the effects.  The only thing that bugged me was that it could be difficult to tell if you were hearing Kazuma speaking or thinking, some more distinction would have been nice.


---

Enjoyment: 10

Overall: 9


It's a parody comedy with adult themes.  If it's the sort of thing you like you'll find it hilarious, if it misses the spot you'll probably find it a bit meh and drop it.  Give it 3 episodes, that should be enough to figure out if you want to watch the rest.


9/10, would "feed" useless party members to a giant toad, again.

My first thought on this anime is simply, it's a great experience. It kept me hooked from the beginning and kept me intrigued through-out. This is the first anime in years that has kept me going back for more.
The story is written in a sarcastic, yet endearing and light way. The clever balance keeps you guessing but also keeps you from creating too much tension. Traditional anime tropes are thrown out for quick (and funny) gags that takes stabs to overly-important anime. When there is depth, it does it well without turning into the thing it wants to parody. Overall, the story is interesting enoughand with strong characters driving the plot forward, it doesn't toss plot for straight parody.


The main character, for the most part, is the everyday man. He has his own personality and commentary. Along with his sometimes impulsive decisions reflect how actual humans work and not shy "B-But" anime dudes behave. Again, this reflects back to it's jabs at traditional anime that tries too hard to make the main character an real hero and instead makes him a real human being.


The music and sound production are great additions too. Mostly the music is played for each scenario, but sometimes used as a joke. The sound quality and production is great, keeping things dynamic and fresh without burning you out with the same 2000s anime sounds that Love Hina made popular.


Overall, it's an enjoyable anime, definitely not one of the best but an amazing one, indeed.


The middle ground of self-awareness and story this anime has is a great combination that is sure to make you enjoy the ride. The presentation and pacing keep you watching without making you exhausted from 50 more episodes of standing angry heroes grunting at the villain who is powering up for a super move. Overall, 8/10 (7.5 tbh but this site doesn't like decimals.)

I CAN see why people like this series, but personally, nah.
The best in the anime does come in its comedy, whether it be slapstick humor or just people saying stupid stuff.  Over time, this did get a bit repetitive, Idk I kinda got bored after a little bit (finished it anyway hooray me!).  
Also if you like seeing the same 10 second scene repeated over the course of 2 episode then yoyu've come to the right series.
WARNING the ecchi grows as the anime progresses (seriously heed it if you want to stay pure).
Overall, outstanding humor, just not suitable for like 40% of theaudience

Maybe Kazuma shouldn't have picked the "Party Hard" option. *ba-dum-tish*
Story:
Kazuma died (hilariously) and now has the choice to either go to heaven or to an RPG fantasy world. Due to circumstances he drags the goddess giving him this choice with him into the RPG world and now they have to do what people in RPGs do. This is clearly a parody of anime like Sword Art Online & co. And it does a great job. All the genre awareness of Kazuma and the (somewhat) uselessness of his comrades make for a great comedy that hardly anybody expected to be this good. But it is, verygood.

9/10


Art:

I personally didn't mind, but the artwork is merely mediocre. In some episodes this is more visible, in others less. They did a good job with special effects like Megumins explosions, but the character designs could have been better. Fans of the light novel will be especially disappointed, as the original art looked much more amazing.

5/10


Sound:

The opening and ending were fair enough, nothing that blows you away but nice to the ear. The background music was not too special, but also fair enough (with maybe the exception of Megumins spell casting, that sounded pretty cool). However, the voice acting was really great. Aqua sounded as annoying as possible, Kazuma sounded very sarcastic and pissed off, Megumin sounded cute but determined and Darkness sounded noble and horny. All the side characters did well too.

8/10


Characters:

I loved them. Being parodies of RPG characters, they are unique enough to stand on their own feet. Instead of being a love interest to the male mc, Aqua was a huge annoyance to him. Kazuma himself was not heroic at all, but a huge prick. Megumin was the most "normal" of the main cast, but very entertaining as well. The only one lacking a bit characterization was Darkness. I'm sure there's more to her, but we didn't see it yet, so in this first season she's merely a running gag. The rest of the cast did what they had to do, only Wiz got a little more spotlight as a nice lich.

9/10


Enjoyment:

The most important aspect of a comedy is to make the viewer laugh. I'm a tough customer when it comes to that, but KonoSuba made me laugh my ass off (literally, I had to glue it back on). Even if you haven't seen any RPG anime before, there are still tons of jokes and funny scenes one can enjoy. The humor often comes at the expense of the characters, which could be considered "mean" by some, but never are they portrayed as completely unlikeable. This sleeper hit of Winter 2016 is a good choice if you are in need of a good laugh [/shameless shilling].

10/10


Overall:

8.2/10

I watched this series because some people are hyping this anime on most of the  groups and anime sites I had visited. 
Overall, it's fine. 
Story seems funny and moving away from the cliche MC shounen protagonist everyone is expecting a series should have which is a good point.
Most of the scene are repetitive mostly from the first few episodes which is kinda meh.. 
Characters are somehow a ripoff of other series with some adjustments..
Start with chuunibyou wizard which other people should know who since she have an eyepatch.
Crusader aka Saber that is a pervert lol.
etc.
As I said, the series is fine but itdoesn't live up with the hype everyone saying that this is the best series or so whatever.\n\n

Kono Subarashii Sekai ni Sh... WAY TOO LONG.
The shortened version, KONOSUBA is what I will refer it as from now on. And don't worry if you forget that nickname because the show will be sure to remind you of it every 5 minutes. But that's not a bad thing: even the anime itself acknowledges that its title is way too long but at least they're not taking it seriously. Anyway, let's start the actual review.
Konosuba is a comic approach on the traditional "sent to a fantasy world" setting. In fact, it is more of a satirical story - every element of the story (be itsetting, characters, plot, etc.) is taken from the traditional RPG world we are used to and made fun of. 


The story is basically about a guy called Kazuma who dies and after being told by a goddess that he can be reincarnated with a single wish into a fantasy world, he chooses to drag her along with him into this RPG-like new adventure. Since this is not what the goddess wanted, the both of them are now set on a quest to defeat the Demon Lord: thing that will allow the goddess to go back home and Kazuma to having actually accomplished something this time around.


Now, the actual progression of the story towards that goal is rather... odd. The pacing is so random that at times the anime feels like a slice of life and at times it feels like important progression is actually being made. It is so weird that even when something does happen I couldn't figure out if it actually any significance for the future in terms of plot advancement. You might thing that this is bad and to be honest, in most cases it is in fact a deal-breaker. But to my enjoyment, not here.


Because who cares about pace when you're laughing your ass off constantly? 


I will have to admit I don't laugh very often in front of anime. I am usually reluctant to watch comedies as they very often use the same old jokes over and over and are filled with clichés. But for once, I found Konosuba to have a refreshing humour and although some of the jokes are nothing new, the situations and personality of the characters more than make up for that in most cases.


One thing that makes this whole comedy work is how well every funny element fits within the story. Unlike many, many mediocre or at most decent comedies, every joke, every funny trait of character and every irregularity is actually part of the overall story and kept as part of its setting. 


To illustrate what I am saying, here is an example: at the beginning of the anime, we are introduced to a creature akin to a big frog. This is a low level monster that our main characters have to defeat in order to "level up", just like your usual slime. It turns out that these frogs get our main heroine all slimy and that's basically the joke. Good. But to keep the consistency of the story, these frogs that would usually get dismissed as soon as the joke is finished, are continually being referenced or reintroduced later on. 


To me, this is what makes this comedy a very good one. The technique of repeating the same patterns of speech over and over again is abused, but in a refreshing and fitting way that actually fleshes out the character. For instance, the way our protagonist Kazuma often says "Yes, yes, I'm Kazuma" whenever one of his teammates is being stupid or perverted is something I found particularly amusing and it helped me understand what kind of person Kazuma is a bit better (essentially someone who really can't be bothered with this crap anymore).


Now that this is out of the way, onto the not-so-good. Konosuba's primary weakness is most likely its animation. While I heard some people criticizing the artstyle, I would say that this is debatable and it may please some. The backgrounds are actually pretty well done. However, the animation isn't exactly something you'd find amazing in 2016. Since this anime has a fair share of fan-service, one of the most noticeable failures of the animation is probably the animation of the famous "boob physics". But then again, I don't think most people watch Konosuba for its ecchi so much as for its comedy so the animation is probably not as important. 


The characters fulfilled their roles of being funny to me and that's mainly due to their personality. The main characters are often performing the usual "boke and tsukommi routine" (basically the idiot and the straight man) with our protagonist always being the tsukommi (straight man). I have to say though, what makes the characters so damn funny is probably how well the voice actors performed. Not only for the main cast but also the side character. Every one of them was acted as if they had an importance of their own, even when they didn't. And this brings me to another point about the characters that I found hilarious: even minor characters whose names are not even introduced are memorable. They are memorable because as mentioned before, they actually belong in this setting and they are seen multiple times, no matter how little attention is put on them. Even the unnamed crowd is full of people that we see over and over again, instead of just random nobodies.


As for the music, the OP is nothing to talk about and the ED fits the anime rather well I thought: using traditional instruments to give off a fantasy vibe and a slow pace to reflect the fact that the show takes things at its own pace. One track in particular that I found memorable was the choir played during the preparation of the spell "Explosion". The fact that it is so intense and at the same time contrasts with the often silly casting time of the spell which literally always varies in length for no actual reason is pretty funny.


Overall, Konosuba was a breath of fresh air in terms of comedy. Honestly, it felt like I was watching an episode of "SAO: Abridged". And that is a compliment. This is obviously not an anime you want to watch if aiming for a serious show but if you feel like turning off your brain, then this is probably amongst the funniest anime I could recommend you to watch.


Really looking forward to season 2.

The premise is about Kazuma Satou voiced by ''Jun Fukushima'' an ordinary high school student, gamer and NEET who died from an average day walking from home trying to save someone. He reawakens in the afterlife and is greeted by a rude goddess Aqua voiced by ''Sora Amamiya'' telling him that he can either go to heaven or be resurrected in an RPG world to defeat the Demon King, she also tells him that he can bring one thing into this world, after much deliberation and annoyance, Kazuma brings the GODDESS into the world. Thus hilarity ensues as Kazuma and Aqua enters the RPG world,but can they survive this RPG world?. Ok so this is a comedy anime that takes many of the "guy goes into the RPG world and becomes a badass" cliches and turns it up it's head and makes fun of it. For example, within the premise, once Kazuma and Aqua enter the RPG world, they join a guild and in order for them to even get money and have a stable income, they do CONSTRUCTION work just to get by, that's playing against LA's expectations. The comedy is rather sadistic but for what comedy is well LA knows it's subjective but still comedy is about "laughing at someone else's misery" and it does it brutally but with "punchlines" with some very good timing and LA loves this anime because of it. The characters are also "playing against the norm" from typical "badass" going into a RPG world cliches, the main protagonist Kazuma is utterly weak in battle with some thief stats but has HUGE amount of karmic/great luck, Aqua is magically potent but has little intelligence, Megumin voiced by ''Rie Takahashi'' an Explosion Mage can only do ONE spell and that usually ends up doing collateral damage AND ends up making Megumin fatigued due to how much magic she expends, finally the last member of Kazuma's party is Darkness voiced by ''Ai Kayano'' a masochist knight who can't HIT anything due to her low accuracy who revels in being in pain (taking the term Tank into a comedic level), Megumin has to be LA's favourite character as her explosion gag can get inventive considering how it was used in the anime's plot, Darkness' masochist gag can be funny similar to Megumin's, however Aqua can be annoying as all she does complain, and Kazuma although he can be a huge douche at times, it can be even worse when interacting with Aqua, but due to the comedy LA kinda wants to see them MORE in this misery for the SAKE of comedy, see what LA means by the comedy being rather brutally sadistic?. Whether it be sadistic or not, it's still funny as hell and LA won't take that KonoSuba is one of the funniest animes from Winter of 2016 because of it. Now in terms of animation, well done by Studio Deen, the character designs are the biggest hit for this animation, with the battles and backgrounds taking a better look at the animation, however LA kinda finds it funny that the character designs are "weak" although it kinda emphasizes the entire "playing against the guy going into an RPG world and becoming a badass" into the animation with it's weak character designs (though the character designs do look unique at least). LA will note that the plot does have interweaving sub-plotlines that allows the plot to move forward through the parties actions (though there are some plotlines that are isolated cases within the one episode) that makes the comedy even better. How is the ending?, well even though they make it climactic as possible it's kinda brings in what it is typical of KonoSuba with that karmic luck added in for good measure. Overall there's not much LA can say but KonoSuba is one of the best comedy anime of Winter 2016 and LA can't wait to see more, ohh wait..they just announced a second season~!!!. YASHHHHH~!!!.

Hey kids!  You know those fantasy RPG games you played when you were young, or play now?  Well, wouldn't it be great to go into one of those kinds of worlds?!  Well, KonoSuba: God's Blessing on This Wonderful World! is the perfect show for you!  Let's go on an adventure!!!  
Side note:  Don't take that introduction even with a grain of salt, this world is fucking terrible.
Story:  Satou Kazuma is your average NEET in the countryside.  Being a lover of games, anime, manga, what have you, Kazuma finally set foot outside his hovel of a room tobuy a limited edition game (or something) until he...well, died.  (It's unfortunate, I know, but when you hear how he died, it's actually quite the story.)  As such is with life, he was given the chance to go to either go to heaven or into a different world thanks to the 'supreme goddess Aqua-sama' granting him a second chance at life.  Thinking that he would go onto some grand adventure, Kazuma jumps on the opportunity to go on the adventure of a lifetime after snatching the goddess away with him...only to find out that this world is more trouble than it's actually worth.  Oh boy.  


The story of Konosuba largely revolves around Kazuma's new life as an adventurer in this new world.  As with all shows that follow a fantasy RPG storyline, he is given stats, goes on quests, gains experience, etc, with just a little...hit of real world realism put into it.  Because instead of an idealistic 'defeat the demon lord' story where Kazuma journeys to the edge of the world/dark realm or some shit, we are instead treated to the life of a freelancer who doesn't have a sustainable source of income solely because he is someone who does odd jobs for people who pin tasks and requests on a corkboard.  It's a very refreshing way of going at this style of story as it satirizes practically every aspect of a traditional fantasy RPG from the way the supposed 'evil' characters act, to the repercussions with every task.  (So...much debt.  Just...so much debt.)


Honestly though, that's all the story really has to offer.  Every new episode is a new episode that had the characters deal with a new quest or event that occurs, before having them claw their way out of the situations they're placed in due to either their own incompetence and idiocy or because things just don't turn out the way they want them to.  Usually both.  Its story is light and easy to follow and largely has a balance of both story and character as neither aspect really takes over one another and the series just sort of drives itself.  The only critique I could really give this show is that there isn't much beyond this satirical comedy, and that the anime is only 10 episodes, much shorter than your average cour.  Even so, there really isn't much to say about Konosuba in the negative aspect.


Overview:

+  Satirical comedy (well done, might I add)

+  Light and easy to follow story

+  Character and story meshed well

-  Not much in terms of story beyond its comedic value

-  Only 10 episodes  (Why, Deen, why.  Why no full cour.)


Characters:  In conjunction with this rather...odd world that we're in in Konosuba, we have an equally strange yet memorable cast to go along with the wackiness that we are introduced here.


First, we have Kazuma.  As the leader of this party of idiots, Kazuma is the fish out of water character in this new world as he's thrown into a new place with new rules and new people.  As a character, Kazuma is the definition of common sense or the 'straight man' in this whole show, as he consistently without fail, throws around proper logic to any given situation and often makes rude but true comments on any situation or character he comes across that bounce off the current situation so well.  His constant retorts are often the basis for what makes this show's comedic value and contributes to why he's such a good MC in the first place.  And for the most part, the shit he has to deal with on a daily basis really isn't his fault.


Then we have Aqua.  Oh boy...this one.  Aqua is the aforementioned goddess that Kazuma brings into the world with him upon arriving into this 'fantastical world'.  As a goddess, Aqua holds great power and upon arriving, has relatively high stats as mentioned in the series.  However, that's...about as good as she gets.  As a character, Aqua is a whiny, self-absorbed goddess who barely has the competency to heal her party members when they have sustained any sort of damage!  But I digress.  True to her nickname, Aqua is a relatively 'useless goddess' and really doesn't serve much to the series aside from piling up debt from food, piling up more debt from spending too much, and helping out in select fights and being actually useful...only to pile up more debt.  She's a terrible person, but she's entertainingly terrible.


Then there's Megumin.  Short and simple, she's a mage with a pension for explosions.  Lots of them.  As the black mage or attack mage of the party, Megumin holds large power and can deal a devastating attack.  Yes, you read that right; A devastating attack.  In search for the ultimate power of explosions, Megumin can channel all of her magic power to cast powerful explosions that will devastate anything they touch.  The nerf to this OPness is that she can only cast it once a day before becoming useless and even immobile for the rest of the day.  That's some balance right there.  


And finally, Darkness.  As the tank of the group, Darkness is the character that soaks up all of the damage.  And she's really good at it.  She's also a masochist, a really severe one, and is unable to hit anything due to having terrible accuracy.  Safe to say, this group of misfits is quite the dysfunctional party.  Since none of them can really properly do anything right on the field, the situation usually ends in hilarity coupled with Kazuma's usual retorts in order to make the scene just that much more entertaining.  


There really isn't much to say in terms of character development since 

1) The characters don't really change in terms of development or traits

2) The side characters really don't have much importance in this series aside from providing another obstacle in the episode or adding to the funny.


Overview:

+  Memorable main characters

+  Entertaining cast

-   Side characters don't really get all that much attention or importance


Art:  Created by Studio Deen, the infamous studio to have less than average art with their projects, Konosuba...actually looks rather nice.  


The whole series has a light color palette that's very nice and colorful and, while there are some subtle art issues with how the characters look at times, there really isn't much to say badly towards this series.  It's rather standard compared to animation today but there isn't really anything THAT bad to say about it.


In particular, the scenes that have Megumin doing her explody shit were honestly rather nicely done since there were an absurd amount of effects and just overall THINGS going on.  Good on you Deen, don't screw up S2.


Overview:

+  Good art  


Sound:  Konosuba's OST really isn't all that fantastic in terms of memorability.  The show has a very calm and peaceful ED to contrast its hyper and upbeat OP with a few choice BGMs for certain scenes like casting certain spells, but there really isn't much to say about the music about this show.  It's good, but it's not THAT good.  (Also, props to Amamimya Sora.  Your voice for Aqua is irritating.  Annoying well done levels of irritating.)


Personal Enjoyment:  Ah, Konosuba.  You are hilarious, I admit.  There really isn't much to say in terms of how much I enjoyed this series since I've basically been singing its praises.  The whole show is just a big ball of hilarious satire on the way games and sometimes even logic works, with a main protagonist that puts shit into perspective in the most assholey yet true way.  It's great, and all faults of the series can be wiped away just because of how great of a character Kazuma is.


Did I enjoy this series?


Ok, me, is this even a question?  Fuck yes, now let's move on, we're almost done here.


What didn't I like about this series?


Well, I can't say 'it ended' cause S2 is confirmed.  So...just for the sake of complaining, it's 10 episodes long.  I hate it when they're this length.  Not that this one in particular was bad, but 10 episode anime has a habit to be bad when I find them.


Would I recommend this series?


Yes.  It is properly funny and is a well-made comedy series.  There are honestly no complaints I have about this series cause the whole show is very fluent in its delivery and storytelling without, if any, faults in between.  There are a few certain details that I was sad that they cut, but honestly, it's still a good adaptation regardless and should deserve more attention.  Cause I have not enjoyed a good comedy series in a while.

Writing comedy is weird. Breaking the key points of storytelling work as models for humor. Lack of character development, lack of character empathy, plots with major holes, etc all work as phenomenal jokes. Konosuba might be the first anime comedy I've seen that does comedy right in the way that it intentionally breaks storytelling tropes for the sake of a laugh. 
Let's begin with the characters, or I should say "party". The main cast includes Kazuma, Aqua, Megumin, and Darkness. Kazuma, the protagonist, has died and been placed into a fantasy RPG world as reincarnation. He is selfish, spiteful, and materialistic. Aqua, the secondary protagonist,is a goddess which Kazuma brings with him after dying. She is also selfish, a crybaby, and has tons of hubris to boot. Megumin is a wizard who only knows "explosion" magic, and she can only use it once a day, though she brags about being the greatest arch magician in the world. This is perhaps the only thing which she cares about in the world. Darkness is a paladin who is a sexual masochist in every sense of the word. Through the anime we learn Darkness might be the only person who cares about people other than herself...though it seems that this is truly in spite of her well being. 


It's clear these cast of characters are not typical of anime in any sense of the word. They lack the honor to do purposefully good things for other people on a normal basis. They're really all kind of assholes, which ended up reminding me of Seinfeld more than anything. But this provides a phenomenal basis for comedy: we are okay when these characters are hurt, battered, and bruised. This is what makes the Darkness joke last so long without it feeling bland. 


This leads into another important part of what makes Konosuba so funny: it uses old jokes to ground new jokes and finds ways to implement them in a new and creative way each time. This doesn't just include the various mishappenings on some kind of stereotypical quest. The bases for many of the plot events in the show are the driven primarily by the flaws of the characters. This seems to be the intent of the showrunners.


It's worth talking about the art style here as well. There's a lot of "janky" animation in the show, and this isn't the prettiest anime in any way, but I don't think the show would have worked as well if it was. Take for instance the fanservice through the show. Certainly the animators are capable of drawing the typically sexy girl, but choose much more realistic and odd shapes for the girls in the show. This added to the various layers of irony which plague the sexual innuendos throughout the show, especially in the case of Darkness's character. 


The OP for this show certainly is original, well put-together, fun, and conveys the show's mood. The music wasn't absolutely phenomenal or memorable, but maybe this puts the expectation a bit high for a show with limited budget.  


Overall, all of these aspects to Konosuba create an absolutely hilarious and self-aware show. It lacks, in my opinion, the kind of perfection of craft that deserves a perfect rating, but still is phenomenal in its own right. The show's end credits are a sort of homey-feeling montage of the town which the show is set. This somehow works, and I think this is because of the flawed characters. Everyone has unfixable character quirks which plague and shape our everyday lives, and Konosuba's portrayal of characters with this kind of real quality makes it feel kind of homey.


This kind of complexity is what makes Konosuba a great show.

REVIEW WITH NO SPOILERS
Konosuba is the kind of anime that I could classify as the desconstruction of the fantasy gender.
Basicaly all the things that you find in a fantasy/adventure anime are NOT here, actually this things are mocked in Konosuba in the funniest way. The protagonist stronger than the average, the villains that are easily beaten down in the beggining of the show...
We could actually classify this as a parody. But maybe you don't like some things here... like for example the fan service, the animation ugly bugs that happen sometimes... and the supporting characters used as convenient it is for the show.
But if youare looking for a funny, non-sense, and very different kind of adventure/fantasy anime, Konosuba is really appropriated!

*spoilers*
Ko No Su Ba is another common fantasy world series the likes of which has been plaguing the anime industry for the past 2 years. We start off this series by introducing the main character Kazuma Satou, a reclusive video game nerd who is excited to play a newly released MMORPG. Arriving home on his way from the video game store he notices a girl who he assumes is about to get hit by a car and so he pushes her out of harms way, alas Kazuma is struck by the vehicle and is immediately killed. *ehm* yuyu hakusho intro *ehm*
Interestingly, as soon as hedies he enters this sort of secluded chamber-like place where he meets the second main character, Goddess Aqua! Aqua explains to him how he is dead and that, instead of sending him straight to heaven which quote "is a boring place where you just float around" she wants to send him to an alternative mmorpg-like world where he has to defeat the Devil King! Kazuma, not nearly as baffled as he should be, accepts the alternative offer and then Aqua explains how he can take any one power or item with him that will give him an advantage in this world, and so naturally he picks Aqua to take with him.


Shortly after, for lack of better words, a wicked time portal travel dimension scene our two main characters realize living in this mmorpg fantasy like world is a little more difficult than they would have imagined. They start off as noobs in this beginners town where they have to build up there levels and make money from doing quests. Kazuma and Aqua decide they need more partners to help with quests and so Megumin and Darkness find there ways into the group, and so now our main lead character Kazuma is surrounded by 3 females lead characters, I wonder what could happen?? No this is not a harem but it damn well did feel like it in some episodes. 


And so this is how this 10 episode series continued, focusing on quests and some other small story lines. One issue I had with this anime is that I could never really tell how these characters are really progressing, they didn't tell us there levels except in one episode, but there was no context to compare it to so it was pretty much irrelevant. We do figure our early on in this series what skills they're better with such as luck for Kazuma but we don't see or are ever told how there skills progressed. Another issue I had with the series is that its story is as such; kill the Devil King, of whom we never even had one glimpse. They do meet and even fight one of his generals, which was a pretty embarrassing and cringey fight but that happened anyway. In fact, in most fight scenes in this series we see our 3 female main characters doing almost all the fighting begging me to ask the question what is Kazuma good for anyway? 


I can continue to go on with many of the little things that annoyed me about this series but I digress, I doubt that the next season of this show is going to make this one anymore entertaining or worthwhile but who knows maybe they'll finally fight the Devil King. Overall this story, characters and my personal enjoyment was just dreadful, art and sound however were above standard and done really well. 4/10.

9.5/10
To be put short: Best Anime of 2016 
This is one of few 10s I think I will ever give out.
Warning: this review contains some spoilers.
When I first started watching Konosuba, I had no expectations at all. I thought it would be just another anime in a fantasy world like Re:Zero or Sword Art Online... Except I was totally wrong.
This anime is nothing but comedy; the characters are nothing but trolls that just make me laugh.
There is the powerful and the mightiest Goddess whose intelligence is FAR BELOW average human being so that even her intelligence can't be leveled up(Aqua).
There is the very strong magewhose magic is so strong that she can't cast a spell for the next 24 hours after using it, making her useless (Megumin).\n
There is the crusader with almost infinite hitpoints, except that she can't hit an enemy and only thinks of perverted things (Darkness).\n
And finally, we have the biggest troll ever, a character who thought he died from a truck accident saving a girl, although in real life he had been hit by a tractor and died of shock from thinking that he had died from an accident, who steals panties every single time for some reason whenever he uses his skill, and leads the guild of the crazy madhouse (Kazuma).\n\n
Combining these four characters makes nothing but chaos, but in a very humorous way.\n\n
Story: 9/10\n
Funny comedy. Why ask for more? I also like the fact that the anime is set in a fantasy world; I think it would have been pretty boring if it was set in a real word or a game world like Log Horizon.\n
And you will be trolled by the plotline along the way...\n\n
Sound: 10/10\n
The voice actors make this anime sound so funny. I personally like Aqua's voice.\n\n
Character: 9000/10\n
Funniest characters ever. Period.\n\n
Enjoyment: 10/10\n
This is the first anime I would rewatch if I were to rewatch any anime. I just RELISHED it.\n\n
There are so many funny scenes in the anime, but to prevent more spoilers, I will end it here.

This anime is silly and does not take itself seriously. I liked it.
Story:
IT is a non-stop stream of gags centered around various JRPG stereotypes. I've seen people talk about SAO and MMOs when discussing this anime, but I don't see anything like that in the game world, and instead it reminds me of titles like dragon quest. The gags are quite light, blunt and cheap (meaning there are no megaton jokes, that'll cause 15 hour long laughing fit), but there are a lot of them, and they don't really stop. There was one strange episode that was too fanservice-focused compared to the rest of theshow, but aside from that, little to complain about.


Art:

Surprisingly solid. Characters are low-detailed, but on few occasions where anime has to display some magic spells, it looks great. There are some instances of CG being used, but those handled fairly well and do not fully feel out of place. 


Sound:

Surprisingly good music, but it is underutilized. Some of the very short themes sound amazing but the anime doesn't focus on them for long enough. I wish they used the music more.


Characters:

Main character is genre-savvy walking embodiment of sarcasm and reason, the rest are mostly stereotyptes. At least one character looks like complete copy of Rurumo from Majimoji Rurumo, but that's just another stereotype. They don't develop across the series, their main purpose is to demonstrate gags displayed by the story. They aren't deep, but are certainly entertaining.


Enjoyment:

It was much more interesting than I expected. I expected a fairly bad show, and got a fairly interesting one instead.


Overall:

Good if you want a quick laugh or a quick chuckle or two. It is no master piece, but it is surprisingly nicely done. Just don't expect anything deep from it. It is light hearted silly fun kind of show that pokes fun at JRPGs and does not really take itself seriously.

Overall Verdict (5/10):  The show's foundation is comedy and lewdness, at the expense of story.  I found the comedy and video-game world to be a detriment to what could have been an intriguing cast.  It's not that the comedy isn't well done, it's just too much.
(Recommendation at the end of the review.)
Story (2/10):  The story is episodic.  The show focuses mostly on the character's living conditions rather than them moving toward goals or developing as characters.  The video game tropes feel like they're getting in the way of the story rather than enhancing it.  For example, skills areacquired not by training or careful decision, but just at a whim.  Quests are chosen from a board or shouted over a loudspeaker, completed, and hardly spoken of again.


Art (7/10):  Heavily lewd in the form of skin-tight clothes and jiggle physics.  But the art is expressive and does the job.  The party mage's special effects are satisfying.


Sound (6/10):  A mix of good and bad.  Aqua's irritating voice almost forced me to quit the show.  However, the sound design is overall good.  Nothing broke my immersion, the background music isn't repetitive.  However the real gem of the show is the party mage's casting. The sound of it building, and her cast shout are absolutely iconic and a must experience.


Character (4/10):  A mix of good and bad.  All of the extras are forgettable.  The party characters are interesting and I wanted more, but the writing does them no justice. The party members' backstories are never flushed out in any detail, and their gimmicks are what define them.  The show's heavy reliance on comedy blocks any real emotional or weighty interactions between the cast members.


HOW TO WATCH:  I recommend to start watching because there are characters worth knowing who they are, particularly Aqua and the mage's character.  If you're not enjoying the show, you won't miss much by quitting partway.  I would recommend Episode 6 is a good stopping point.  (I say this having not watched Season 2.  Might want to check there to see if I changed my mind.)

Right from the first episode, this anime secures itself as one of the funniest animes out there in the Fantasy genre.  At no point in time does it every relinquish that title, from episode 1 to episode 10. (Episode 5 is especially hilarious.).  
The story follows the similar refrain that you find in fantasy genres nowadays, in that an average loser/NEET (Kazuma) is teleported to another world to be the protagonist in an RPG-styled world.  And while that concept has definitely been played out in recent years, with many animes trying to follow in the footsteps of Sword Art Online, this animenails it, by going in the direction of complete absurdist comedy.  It definitely works based off of the hilarious main characters, Kazuma, Aqua, Megumin and Darkness.  


Of the characters, Kazuma and Aqua stand out the most.  Shrewd, lacking in principles without being blatantly villainous, selfish and deeply flawed people, they are not like your typical starring duo in these types of animes.  And I have to point out I especially love the fact that Kazuma was handled in a way that wasn't scared to death of sexual encounters, and while perverted, not overly so to the point of where his perversion was nose-bleed cliched.   


Now, Kunosuba isn't without it's flaws, either.  The animation is on the low quality side, very similar to that of Log Horizon.  But, it doesn't take away from the anime.  The score is pretty mediocre, just a typical fantasy music score, lots of flutes, like you would expect.  But, what does hurt the anime is Episode 8-10.  Because this is a truncated anime, not a 13 episode season, but only 10, after episode 8, things just start developing without appropriate connection in story telling.  When I watched episode 8, I had to do a double take and make sure I didn't miss an episode.  It felt like I did, as they introduced a new character and situation with such speed and little explanation, it felt like I had missed episode 7 without realizing I did.  


Episode 9 was total filler to just get us to the final episode, but it was absolutely hilarious, so it gets a pass.  But, Episode 10 was a problem.  Even though they had foreshadowed in earlier episodes what eventually made its way to the town in the final episode, when it arrived, it just felt so sudden and without any real build up.  It just felt like another event without much significance.  That's how the last episodes felt like.  Like a string of events without much significance, other than to introduce a new character.  


Still, even though the pacing was severely flawed in the final three episodes, the humor and characters overrode that problem and made the show enjoyable to the end.  I'm looking forward to digging into season 2 right away.  I highly enjoyed the anime, and I think fans of the genre will enjoy it as well.

Enjoyment - 10

Overall – 9

This is the first anime since Clannad to make me cry. Of course this time I was crying from laughing so hard. I would recommend it to anyone that enjoys fantasy or comedy based anime.
Story (8): The anime has a broad continuing story of "to defeat the demon king" but each episode usually revolves around 1 quest. The quest will usually involve a laughable struggle and a lame, lucky success (lame in their effort, but very enjoyable).
Art (10) and Sound (9): The art, animation, and sound are all first rate
Character (7): This is like a double edged sword, the characters are rather 1-dimensional (except forKazuma). However, each character is so polished in their dimension that its acceptable. Kazuma is a well-rounded character who has normal self-interested desires and reacts appropriately to his idiotic party and the unbalanced nature of the world.\n\n
Enjoyment (10): This show is so funny I've cried and even woken my roommate from laughing so hard, and I tend not to like comedy driven animes. However, outside of comedy the show doesn't really shine, the fights aren't spectacular, but to me they are unpredictable; the characters grow as a party, but they stay trapped in their 1-dimension (and Kazuma only grows more frustrated not more developed).\n\n
Overall (9): This show is hilarious and does a good job capturing the fantasy world while being unique. I was expecting a rehash of SAO and Log Horizon, but instead I got a comedy, fantasy, "game" anime that shines in its own light for its own reasons.

Konosuba is one of those shows that ends up being entertaining in spite of itself.  There have been quite a few shows where the protagonist ends up in an alternate reality fantasy world complete with a harem over the last few seasons and years.  Many of these shows are quite mediocre and rely quite heavily on harem tropes and fan service to try to carry the viewers through each episode.  Konosuba doesn't shy away from any of this, and by all that is good and true, should end up being just another poor to mediocre entry into the pile.
Yet... Konosuba stands asan interesting send up of the entire genre and becomes enjoyable regardless.  


Without spoiling the story too much, the basic premise behind the show is that our main protagonist ends up getting "killed" and shipped off to a new life in a fantasy world with one special item/skill what have you facilitated by the goddess he meets after his untimely demise.  He decides, much to the goddess's chagrin, that he wants to take her along, and poof!  Off the two of them go to their new life in what essentially amounts to a more or less standard fantasy world.


Many shows end up trying to make the main character overpowered and completely able to dominate their new world for... some reason or other, probably related to self-insert fantasies.  Konosuba becomes entertaining for the fact that it turns just about every expectation around on you.  


The main character is basically a terrible person and quickly finds that his dreams of being an all powerful demigod won't quite work out because by the statistical power rules of this strange new world, he's painfully average and can't take a powerful role that he wants.  He also quickly finds out that the goddess that he brings along with him is as terrible and self absorbed as he is and that she's not exactly helpful at all either.  The rest of the season is the two of them stumbling through the harsh realities of trying to make a living as adventurers..  


Kazuma, our main hero also collects a couple other misfits who don't really fit into standard heroic teams to round out his "harem" as well, including a send up of the all powerful chuuni mage archetype who boasts incredibly powerful magic!  That can only be used once... Not the most useful teammate.  They also collect a holy crusader character who is in theory incredibly powerful, yet only has usefulness as a meat shield who gets off on being beaten up and treated like a piece of meat often to the detriment of the tactical plan.  The rest of the show is basically these dysfunctional, selfish, downright idiotic personalities accepting quests from a job board Fairy Tail style and hilariously making Kazuma's life incredibly difficult.


On paper, Kazuma lives the ideal life of being a fantasy adventurer surrounded by attractive "powerful" adventurer classes, and many of his other acquaintances envy him... yet his life is a living hell of crazy situations.  That is the overarching schtick of this show that makes it work.


That, more than anything is why Konosuba is a surprisingly entertaining show to watch.  While the art is subpar a lot of the time, and the story is a bit ridiculous, Konosuba succeeds as an entertaining show because the characters interact in ways that just make things funny, even if the jokes are pretty repetitive at times.  There is a great sit-com vibe with the show and the voice actors seem to be having enough fun with this to carry things and make you want to watch these goofballs go out and sort of succeed at adventuring despite their sheer idiocy.


While I cannot claim that this show has any great meaning to it, or does something incredible with the genre (really, the isekai genre isn't that great to begin with), or even that it relies way too heavily on its own memes to overcome its mediocre writing, it really was a fun journey through ten episodes. 


At the end of the day, the measure of an anime stands on whether or not it entertains you, regardless of its other merits or lack there of.


At the end of the day, Konosuba is not a great show, but it is an entertaining one.

A few spoilers ahead probably, mostly of just the first few episodes.
KonoSuba is the first anime i watched during it's airing time, and it sure was great. 
The animation is really colorful and bright, and it has great comedy.
Even though it might seen similar to anime like Sword Art Online for it's "Fantasy-themed video game world", KonoSuba follows a more satirical path., showing how it would be to be in such a world, without actually having any sort of super powers, and having a nearly hopeless party.
The characters themselves are nice, but they're not the most likable besides Megumin (best girl rite here), as Darknessdidn't get as much development besides "perverted masochist". The animation is really great, although breast physics can be really weird, but i'm sure it's like that mostly for comical purposes.\n
Another downside KonoSuba has is lack of episodes. Season 1 ended with only 10 episodes, which is a rare ocurrance on anime, and nobody seems to know why it ended so early. Despite ending so early, an OVA has been confirmed by this Fall season, and a second Season which date has yet to be confirmed.\n\n
While it's not perfect, i highly recomend this anime if you want some nice laughs, as it's comedy is really great.

In the future, if I ever need to point out an example of characters being more important than story, I'm going to point at this show. 
STORY (spoilers):
The story itself is nothing special, really, but it sets everything up wonderfully and has a few hilarious twists. A dude gets teleported to a fantasy world, where he finds instead of being a hero, he's forced to be a laborer and live the minimum wage fantasy life. Every time he saves the day, he still gets screwed over by the consequences of what he does. 
That's my favorite part of the story. Real consequences. He saves histwo female party members from the insides of a frog, but they come out all slimy and the town mistakes him for a pervert, which leads to a perverted crusader seeking him out. The characters save the town by flooding the villain with a torrent of water, but they end up in debt because they destroyed the city wall. They save the day yet again, but the main character is arrested because he teleported the detonating power core right onto the governor's mansion. Nothing ever goes his way and I love it.


CHARACTERS:


This is the sole reason you should watch this show. The characters are f*cking fantastic. Kazuma and gang are a beautiful subversion of every single harem anime out there.


Kazuma is the best main character in a long time. I haven't liked someone this much since Hachiman. He's deadpan, he's cynical, he's pragmatic, he insults the crap out of everybody, he's an amazing straight man in all the antics he's involved in, and he's basically just the subversion of all the infuriatingly bland MCs out there.


One of my favorite character moments for him is when he meets someone who's basically the MC of every other fantasy transportation anime out there. The other guy is annoyingly selfless to the point where people consider him narcissistic, and keeps trying to act how he believes is right. The other person challenges Kazuma to a duel due to a misunderstanding.


Just as the other guy is finished with the challenge, Kazuma quickly says "All right, I'm in." and charges right at him, catching the guy off guard. As soon as the other person tries to defend himself, he steals his magic sword and knocks him out with it. Then he goes to pawn it off to make a boatload of cash.


Kazuma isn't interested in morality or chivalry, he acts in the most pragmatic and logical ways possible. He isn't afraid to take advantage of other people's idiotic tendencies and use it against them. 


There are tons of other character quirks I love. The way he says "Yeah, I'm Kazuma" or "Hi, this is Kazuma" when other people call is name out is a fantastic way of making fun of other animes where characters constantly call out the MCs name. He insults and berates his teammates to push their limits and get them to step up instead of some corny inspirational speech. He fully acknowledges his perverted thought, and eagerly cuts the bullshit to embrace opportunities with the other sex when he gets the chance (like a lot of normal high schoolers). 


Imagine any other MC walking what amounts to a prostitution bar filled with skimpy succubi. They would probably get all flustered, apologize profusely for no fucking reason, and sprint out, right? Kazuma instead asks about possible legal ramifications for some requests that he's about to make to see how far he can push it. A girl barges into the bathroom as he's taking a bath, and his response is a leisurely "yo" with the best shit eating grin you'll ever see. This guy is great.


His chemistry and relationships with the other party members he has are also amazing. He sees himself as their caretaker, but he's pissed off at them for their horrible combat abilities and personality. He spends most episodes insulting the crap out of them, but it's still evident they all care for each other regardless because of how he keeps paying their tabs off.


They're basically like your college roommates. One's lazy and retarded, one 's weird, and the last one is into some really weird sh*t, but you all still hang out due to proximity. Eventually, you're all forced to like each other. That's the character dynamic we're talking about here.


Their relationships are never blatant either, which is f*cking incredible in the world of anime. There are no relationship scenes where they talk about their feelings/backstories and then blush a bunch (by the way, screw these scenes and their cringy dialogue), but their relationships still evolve before your eyes. 


You get the feeling that Kazuma is kind of awkwardly sexually attracted to his party members, but there aren't zoom ins on his blushing face to REALLY MAKE SURE YOU GET THAT HE MAY HAVE A THING FOR THIS ONE. You get the feeling that the other girl might like him back, but there aren't any MEANINGFUL dialogue lines with a SHORT, BUT PROFOUND PAUSE FOLLOWED BY A GASP BY THE MAIN CHARACTER AS HIS DENSE MIND IS FINALLY PROCESSING WHAT SHE MIGHT BE IMPLYING.


Sorry, this is turning into a rant about how much I'm getting sick of all the stock harem anime out there. Which I am, by the way.This anime is a breath of fresh air.

Ok people, there's just some anime you don't critically analyze, you just accept and enjoy what they are, KonoSuba! Is one of those anime.
Who watches KonoSuba for the plot? Nobody, (unless you mean the PLOT, plot ;) )
The 'going to a new world trope has been recycled so much, nobody watches it for the plot.
Basically, KonoSuba is so full of 'un-cliches' that those un-cliches become the cliches of the anime? Makes sense? KonoSuba is funny with its characters and situations and just how brutally, relatably, and realistic some of their problems are. Especially with studio Deen animating it, I was going to be in forquite a ride. Studio Deen's had some pretty strange animating moments (cough cough Higurashi) but it actually turned out for the better in KonoSuba with hilarious badly-drawn faces.\n\n
Overall, just a good time for 10 episodes, I highly recommend the second season two, I wish they went more forward in the plot though. (Also I love the EDs of KonoSuba, so relaxing!)

Alright, so is this anime good? Yes. Is it worth a watch? Maybe, if you're looking for a quick, light-hearted pass time. Is this all it's hyped up to be? Weeeeellll... no. 
I'm not familiar with this kind of fantasy-parallel-universe genre since I don't really know many "good" anime that stems from it, so when people say this is supposed to be a parody of that genre, I have to admit, I really have no clue how accurate that statement is. So I guess some of the humor is lost on me, then. Lucky me.
As a comedy, this didn't really work for me. Not sureif it was just my sense of humor, but a lot of it felt like it was flat and bland. Not saying that it was terrible, but it wasn't anything out of the ordinary, just the kind you typically find in anime. It seemed to fare much better with its longer punch lines and some of its running gags, though after some time, some of those got old quick. I will give the series some credit, since as it went along, it became much funnier and more entertaining, mostly because Darkness became more masochistic (okay, so I might have found that a little funny) and Kazuma became more and more done with everyone's shit. Kazuma cracked me up and probably was what made the show actually decent; he is my spirit animal, god bless his soul.


As for the actual plot... well, not much actually happens, but I don't think anyone was really expecting it to since it's a comedy. Which is kind of a bummer, because I really wanted to see them actually go on genuine adventures and defeat the Devil King and stuff. It gets a little boring when they're just doing the same things over and over again. Because - news flash - humor works just as well (if not better) if you actually spice things up a little. New settings are okay to use every once in a while - it won't detract from the fact that this is a parody (?) if you do it.


The art was pretty, but nothing special, especially for something made so recently. The character designs were pretty bland, especially for something supposedly set in a fantasy world, famous for its elaborate and creative character designs. Nope. None of that here.


The sound was probably one of the high points of the anime. While the opening sounded like something out of Love Live (aka bland and overdone) and the ending was too quiet for my taste (though it was pretty peaceful, which I'll give it credit for), the voice actors and their line delivery was what made me laugh sometimes rather than the actual jokes. Kazuma's tone  when talking to the girls and Aqua's screams and wailing were absolutely perfectly done and quite hilarious, and the way the music swiftly switched on and off when something anticlimactic happened was entertaining, so kudos to the creators for that.


The characters were (ugh, I'm going to get a lot of hate for this) overall really bland and boring. Actually, Kazuma was the most interesting, because he was the most relatable: "Why am I here? What am I doing? This isn't the kind of fantasy world I imagined; I hate it." Darkness was probably the only girl I actually really liked, mostly because I kind of found her masochism amusing and her personality a little unique. Aqua was quite annoying, to say the least, and though I thought Megumin was cute, she was nothing special, as I've seen multiple characters just like her in the past. For a parody anime, it doesn't do too good of a job parodying tropes, now, does it?


I enjoyed this anime... I guess. I mean, I watched the entire season, and I'm planning to watch the next (and the next, when that comes out) so I guess I found it entertaining? Strangely enough, it stands out a little among others of its like, so I guess that might be it. I think the best way to describe it is it's one of those stupid cat videos on Youtube that wastes your time and are absolutely ridiculous, and yet you just can't stop watching them. But in all honesty, this review was probably a little harsh purely because of the high expectations that everyone set for this anime (and my terrible sense of humor), so I guess it didn't really reflect my true feelings. 


Overall, this anime isn't terrible, but it's not as mind-blowing as everyone says it is. It's good and it's cute, and if you want a few laughs or just something a little silly and slightly entertaining to watch, then give this a go. If you're expecting something like Gintama or Nichijou, then you should probably go find something else to watch instead, since this is nowhere near that level of comedy.

Konosuba is one of the funniest shows that I have seen, period. Throughout the show there was rarely a time where I wasn't laughing my ass off.
Konosuba though doesn't really have a strong story, or really one at all. Sure there is a big baddy set up, but it never goes anywhere. Konosuba instead takes the episode by episode route of telling a story, where almost each episode tells a different story than the last. In that aspect, the story is gold, the episodes plot-lines are all funny and there are great jokes spread throughout.
I do have one issue with the show though and thatis with its treatment of the character Darkness. Darkness is kinda just thrown to the sidelines and never gets as much time spent to her as the others do, though this is just a small problem and doesn't detract from the enjoyment that I got out of the series.\n
All said and done, Konosuba is an amazing comedy, with fantastic jokes, good characters and some damn good parodies of other big shows, I couldn't recommend it more.

I see that most people are categorizing this as harem, but it's really not. That's what makes it entertaining. The whole thing is set up to be a classic "MC is stuck in a fantasy world with a bunch of chicks who are into him", but that's not the way it goes.
Here's why it's not a harem:
First, the MC is just a regular otaku, who, when placed in a fantasy world is... shockingly underpowered. Basically, the only stat going for him is luck, which ends up playing only a minor role in the rest of the story.
Second, the girls in his group are all weirdand quarky, and none of them particularly want to get involved with him.


Third, there's no real villain they're trying to defeat. I mean, with some episodes there are bad guys who pose a threat, only to be taken down in the most embarrassing and silly ways, but apart from that there's no main enemy.


=========


Honestly, the beginning of the show was a bit too slow, in my opinion. I felt like the first few episodes could have been compressed a bit more, but around the 4th episode, the setup was complete and the show really found it's stride. Episode 5 had me laughing the entire time, and from then on, the pacing was much better.


I'm excited to hear that the second season was confirmed, and hope it continues on with the same quality as this one.

When writing this review, I asked myself: why did I rate Konosuba so highly?  Was it because it did something new?  Was it because it made me look at an old thing in a new light?  No.  The answer isn't something so complicated as that.  Why is Konosuba a masterpiece?  It made me laugh.
Konosuba is, when all the trappings and bells and whistles are taken away, a comedy.  What does a good comedy do?  It makes the viewer laugh.  A great one?  Peals of laughter.  A Konosuba one?  Gasping for air and needingto pause while waiting for your seizure to stop.



Story: 9/10

The basic idea has already been done time and time again.  Isekai is nothing new.  Getting game-breaking weapons is nothing new.  But Konosuba takes all that and throws it out the window.  The MC, Kazuma, dies a hilarious death and winds up in a sort of purgatory in front of the goddess Aqua.  She throws him a bunch of very OP weapons and abilities and tells him to choose from the lot, all the while poking fun at his laughable death.  Understandably pissed off, Kazuma decides to pick her instead of the weapons, and their wild adventure begins!  Naturally, there is a plot, but it isn't so much a plot as it is a bunch of loosely connected episodes.  While Kazuma and his gang do level up and gain more powers and abilities, the whole adventure winds up being not so much an MC and his gang lvl up and proceed to beat the snot out of the end boss so much as it is a slice of life with fantasy elements.  In fact, the first episode does a marvelous job of depicting the flow of time as Kazuma and Aqua perform their jobs as adventurers by building houses and completing no quests at all.  Episode 2 sees the start of their adventuring, but hilarity ensues as they complete their kill quest in not quite the manner they envisioned it, particularly from Aqua's viewpoint; she certainly didn't think she'd be used as bait.  Ep 2 also sees the introduction of the 3rd member of our cast, Megumin.  Although she seems, and is, weird from having a chuunibyou name and personality, she quickly absolves their worries after demonstrating her very real and very deadly EXPLOSION (cue collapse from awe).  Ep 3 introduces us to our final cast member: Darkness.  A masochistic crusader, she demonstrates her value to Kazuma's party by allowing flying vegetables to strip her of her armor, all in front of ogling men (who're staring for entirely different reasons).


After getting us introduced to the four main cast members, we find that they proceed to, aside from one or two notable deeds, do absolutely nothing, all while comfortably vegetating in the starting town.  While they do nothing, how they do it is priceless.  Which leads us to the next criterion:



Characters: Konosuba/10

In any story, whether it be a book, an anime, or a movie, the characters will make or break the narrative.  This is even more apparent in slice-of-life anime, since it really just follows the characters as they do their daily, often boring, business.  Thus, the individual characters and their chemistry are especially important; Konosuba does not disappoint.  In order of first appearance in the anime, we have:


Kazuma-

Your typical MC protagonist, except he's not.  While he fits the NEET archetype, he fills in other archetypes as well, such as the pervert, the asshole, and the, surprisingly useful, hero.  Throughout the series, we see Kazuma grow both in levels and as a person.  While he still is a hikikomori by the end of the series, he's gone from (hasn't talked to a girl in his life, stays at home playing games) to (talked to N+1 girls, stolen panties off of girls N+1 times, saved the town multiple times by accident and by design, and most importantly, gotten better at dealing with people, specifically, his 3 problem children).  He has grown from a self-centered pervert to someone who, while still selfish and perverted, better understands how to deal with people in interactions ranging from idle chit-chat to business transactions.  This is probably thanks to his trial by fire known as, in no particular order (AquaMeguminDarkness).  He's also gotten a variety of skills that allow him to better deal with enemies.


Aqua-

The typical perfect bishoujo (she's a goddess for crying out loud), save this one's a bitch instead of an ice queen, and as Kazuma finds to his great dismay, completely and utterly useless.  She introduces herself to Kazuma by proclaiming that she's a goddess before openly laughing at his death (though let's face it, we would too).  After getting dragged to the fantasy world, her first act is to bawl like a baby.  Her tantrum is then catapulted into the spotlight since the episode puts her wailing on pause (it's like even the director got sick of her), before allowing her tears to run their inevitable course.  The first episode does a marvelous job of highlighting her bitchy antics without making the viewer outright hate her.  The later episodes expand on her character, and by the end of the series, though she's still clumsy and a bitch, she's become slightly better mannered and more competent combat wise (cue classic breaking of shield of end boss).  We, and Kazuma, grow to like this girl (just a little bit though)


Megumin-

What happens when you take 8th grade syndrome and make it real?  You get the meme known as Megumin.  While her chunni antics are decidedly weird, and at times, outright perverted, she is very powerful, as demonstrated by her EXPLOSION, first witnessed in ep 2.  Just like her trademark attack, she is very flashy and very red.  She's smart too, as she coerced Kazuma into letting her join his party despite the latter trying, not so subtly, to eject her.  For the first half of the season, she mainly serves as the fireworks of the gang, or in this case, causing an OP boss to attack them before they were properly prepared.  The latter half of the season sees Megumin use a better EXPLOSION, but there's not too much personal growth.


Darkness-

What do crusaders do?  They protect people.  Now let's dial it up past MAX and throw away the sword.  The end result is the running gag known as Darkness.  Probably the most one-dimensional character of the series, Darkness nonetheless provides excellent fun and demonstrates the delight of taking a concept and turning it up to 11.  Her gag is the foil to the folly the other 3 characters invariably encounter.  Perhaps inevitably, she doesn't experience any notable growth; that's saved for season 2.


Now the chemistry:

Kazuma is, not too surprisingly, the most level headed of the gang.  He provides a source of stability whenever the others get too out of hand, though if they really decide to go all out, he's dragged along for the ride.  He provides a relatable viewpoint, whether through his deadpan humor and snide remarks or through his not so exaggerated reactions (some'll still be exaggerated to the moon and back).  Aqua is the foil he plays off of.  She's pretty much the opposite of everything Kazuma is.  One is decent with money; the other is spenderific.  One is somewhat able to analyze the situation; the other has no clue at all.  One manages not to set off any traps; the other sets off all the traps and attracts traps outside the dungeon!  In other words, one is the boke and the other is the tsukkomi.  The fantasy world setting frees the characters to do pretty much whatever they want cuz in the end, it's all magic.  This allows Konosuba to dial all the antics up to 11.  Then we have Megumin. 

 She's another boke, but unlike most boke, she's actually smart and able to read the situation.  From taking advantage of whispered rumors to force her way into Kazuma's party to coordinating with Kazuma as a team to fight the midboss, she actually contributes to the team's fighting strength.  Ofc, the only reason they had to fight the midboss in the first place was because she made it mad.  Then we get Darkness.  As Aqua was Kazuma's foil, Darkness is the foil of the other 3.  Her masochistic desires make light of what could've otherwise been a relatively serious situation.  Her longing to be covered in slime or get blasted with fire light up an otherwise dark encounter.  While we all know that the main 4 are going to get away unscathed (?), Darkness's unrequited desires provide a comfortable denouement to the climaxes.



Art: 9/10

1. The action scenes (fights, giant laser beams, EXPLOSION, tantrums) were gorgeous

2. The vibrant colors and varied outfits of the cast members were pleasing to the eye; the secondary characters had outfits no less varied

3. If it takes 1 hour to draw one scene and there are 12 scenes per second, how long would it take for one person to animate an entire episode?



Sound: 9/10

OP and ED were pleasing.  The OP especially synced exquisitely with the animation.  It's like a story within a story.  The other sounds, tones, and music within Konosuba did well in highlighting the antics of the gang or helping tone down the mood.



Enjoyment: ???/10

In the end, Konosuba is, at it's core, a slice-of-life comedy in a fantasy world.  As I noted at the beginning of my review, it caused me to laugh so hard I needed to press pause.  Need I say more?


Overall: 9.5x/10 (9.6x?)

Konosuba is a wonderful departure from the standard isekai genre.  It starts out with fittingly 1D characters before slowly fleshing them out through, delightfully, everyday occurrences (if you can call monsters an everyday occurrence).  Admittedly, as this is comedy at it's core, the gags and jokes are not for everyone.  Some people prefer deadpan humor, some like sitcoms.  I like sitcoms.  I like manzai.  Konosuba is an excellent sitcom.  It is an excellent manzai.  The fantasy setting allows Konosuba to create wild situations that would otherwise break our suspension of disbelief, and the characters themselves provide relatable viewpoints and mood lighteners.  All in all, Konosuba is comedy platinum.


P.S.

Last episode has a hilarious twist at the end, setting up a natural segue into season 2!

Ahhh Konosuba, an anime that many people like myself went in with little to no expectations (doesn't help when it's by DEEN). And oh boy what a surprise it was.
Story (7/10):
About Konosuba's story, there wasn't really one. Many have come to expect a MMORPG setting with similar stories and tones like SAO, Log Horizon, Overlord, Danmachi etc. However, Konosuba is more of a SOL parody with the MMORPG setting with more focus on the comedy aspect. The story is being told in an episodic manner with the group dealing with MMORPG issues like recruitment, money management and of course the quests. Except being a parody,they are not your typical MMORPG issues you would expect, and for the better good from a comedic standpoint. That said, despite me liking the SOL parody setting and the comedy, the story is not one of its main selling points.



Art (6/10): 


Studio DEEN is notorious for having terrible art and animation. Hence, expectations were not high going into this anime. Luckily they stepped it up this season. The art style isn't noticeably special, but appealing to a relaxing, comfy and funny anime like Konosuba. The explosions by Megumin however look neat. The animation is decently fluid, although there isn't a huge amount of movements. The brighter colors are also a plus as it fits the lighter tones of the show. The character designs are decent, not bizarre but also not lazy with some details on their outfits. One important thing to note is how freaking silly their reaction faces are, in a good way. Overall, I have little complains regarding the art and animation as a whole, despite some questionable shots. At least DEEN didn't pull a...DEEN. 



Sound (7/10):


The voice actors suits the characters as you would expect from looking at the character designs. The voices are still great considering some of them aren't even that experienced as a voice actor. The background music fits the story and atmosphere well albeit not amazing. There are no noticeable tracks that really captured my attention which is slightly disappointing considering the music composer is known for his works in the Monster Hunter series.


The opening and ending songs on the other hand, are excellent. The opening is upbeat and cheerful which perfectly matches the tone of the show. However, what I really want to talk about is the ending theme. I might be bias as I love theme songs which are sung by the voice actors of the MCs, but the ending theme is stupendous. It is really comfy and relaxing and surprisingly fits the show well. It gives off a homey feel after a crazy absurd episode of Konosuba. 


Characters (10/10):


The characters are by far the main reason why this show is good. I'm going to first talk about the main cast, Satou, Megumin, Aqua and Darkness. In terms of their power level, they have huge flaws but huge strengths. Like being able to tank tons of damage but unable to land a single hit. The show makes uses of said flaws and strength for comedic purposes and it is executed well. For their personalities, the male MC, is by far one of the best MCs for a show like this. He is a dick, in a good way. He is straightforward and not afraid to call out the stupid things the girls in the group are doing and trolls people for his own enjoyment. At the end of the day however, he still meant well for the girls and can be sensible at times. The personalities of the girls are pleasantly surprising for their designs, which of course adds to the humor of the show. They are not normal, and being out of the norm is what a show like this needs. Some might argue that the group gets too close and bond to each other way too fast, but I feel that it is perfectly fine due to episode restrictions. 


The side characters are not that interesting and are forgettable which is not a big problem considering the little impact they have on the show. The villains, well, there aren't really any villains. Other than monsters they fight, the 'villains' are just annoying to the main cast and nothing more.  Overall, despite the main cast having barely any character development, it is not necessary for a show like Konosuba, where people like me just watch the show for the characters usual antics. 



Enjoyment (10/10):


The comedy of this anime is simply fantastic. And is something I really look forward to every week for my weekly laughs after a long day of school. I love comedy anime and in fact more than half of all the anime I've watched has comedy in them, be it main or subplot.
